deck_description: Strong Neo-Spacian deck that doesn't rely on combo.  A fun alternative to the ordinary HERO list.     This deck has 7 hard bricks that you don't want to draw (3x Neos, Rainbow Dragon, Burstinatrix, Avian, Neo space). You could reduce this to 6 bricks by swapping out "Favourite hero" and "Neo Space" (as neo space is the weakest card on this list).

deck_excerpt: Check This Out!!
deck_description: This build has a focus on solely using one of the two variations of the one card combo, or, if you have 2 prank-kids in your hand, 2 card combos that only summon 4 times in a turn. With the room saved from not needing polymerization, ultra polymerization, or cards that search them, it is able to play a plethora of hand traps, making it much stronger at going 2nd compared to other builds, while not sacraficing much strength in going first.     This build is focussed more on TCG rules, even though it has crossout designator. Parallel exceed cannot chain block using OCG rules like it can here in the TCG:/     Either way, this is a super rewarding deck to become familiar with!

deck_excerpt: Step 1: Get out Photon Satellite ASAP  Step 2: Stall and let Photon Satellite Boost up it's level each turn  Step 3: ???  Step 4: Profit
deck_description:
Target: Get The Calculator to millions of ATK points. Since almost anything meta relevant can deny the attack of  The Calculator or destroy the setup even before it's happening, this is an absolute Gimmick Deck! Build: The only cards you really need are: 3x Photon Satellite & 3x The Calculator I also highly recommend to run 3x Machine Duplication in order to get 3 Photon Satellite on the board ASAP. The rest of the deck are just generic stall or draw cards. Strategy:
  1. Get Photon Satellite out ASAP
  2. Stall the duel so Photon Satellite are multiply their level each turn.
  3. If you reached the desired total level, summon The Calculator
  4. If you play against a heavy backrow deck, maybe put some backrow-removal cards in your deck (see sidedeck)
  5. Go for lethal with your millions of ATK

deck_excerpt: Not sure if it's would be a "Meta" deck because the deck is far too reliant on the extra deck and has nothing to take care of pesky cards that prevent
deck_description: Main Strategy- Special Summon and excavate. Adamancipator Analyzer special summons himself if you have no monsters, then excavate and special summon Adamancipator Crystal - Dragite if possible. If not, either of the other two Adamancipator Crystal monsters will do. Adamancipator Researcher Special Summons herself when you have another Rock-type monster on the field then excavate and special summon Adamancipator Crystal - Raptite. If not, the other two will do. Admancipator Seeker summons himself if you have another "Admancipator" monster is on the field. Then once again excavate and special summon Adamancipator Crystal - Leonite if possible, other wise like the other two go for the other Adamancipator Crystal monsters. Once you have used any of your Tuners' effects, Synchro summon for any of the Adamancipator Risen monsters. Your main boss monsters are in order. Adamancipator Risen - Dragite. Not only does he give a strong field advantage when using his excavation skill allowing you to return opponents cards to their hand up to the No. of excavated Rock-type monsters by this effect. During your Opponents turn he can negate any one effect and destroy it as long as you have a WATER monster in your graveyard. Making him a great disruption card. Adamancipator Risen - Leonite allows you to add 1 excavated "Adamancipator" card to your hand, and if you have a FIRE monster in your graveyard during your opponents turn you can special summon any Rock-type monster from your graveyard. Leonite's first ability is great to add a little extra padding if you are in need of it, or setting up for your next turn. Adamancipator Risen - Raptite is much like the Adamancipator "Tuners" in the aspect of special summoning an excavated monster, but this time its not limited to only "Non-Tuner" monsters. If you have a WIND monster in your graveyard you can banish one of your opponents cards in their graveyard during their turn. This card is best candidate to Syncrho summoning Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon using any level 2 "Tuners" you may have on hand. Adamancipator Laputite the field spell card allows you to stack your deck and gives a nice 500 ATK and DEF boost to all your Rock-type monsters. So if you are able to summon Adamancipator Risen - Dragite, Adamancipator Risen - Leonite, and Adamancipator Risen - Raptite and have Adamancipator Laputite on the field on your first turn. Is a perfect set up for ant FTK. Use Adamancipator Laputite to stack the top of your deck with five "Adamancipator" monsters then useing Adamancipator Risen - Dragite effect to return practically all of your opponents cards to their hand. Basically leaving your opponent wide open for 9,100 worth of damage ending the dual. If you don't have Analyzer in your hand but you have Doki Doki plus any of the Koa'ki Meiru monsters. This sets you up to search out and summon Analyzer. By first normal summoning Doki Doki then using Doki Doki's effect by discarding the Koa'ki Meiru and then proceed to search and summon Analyzer. Then excavate, summon and Syncrho summon. If your Adamancipator Risen monster are defeated don't worry too much. As long as their corresponding Adamancipator Crystal monster is in the graveyard you can return them to the extra deck as long as they are not banished also recycling the Adamancipator Crystal back to the top of your deck. As for the Adamancipator Crystals' first effects. Dragite's is the best, when it is special summoned by one of the Apamancipators' effects allows you to draw a card. Leonite will allow you to recycle any "Adamancipator" card to the top of your deck from your graveyard or your hand. Great for recycling used spell or trap cards. Raptite will recycle any Rock-type monster to the top of your deck from either the hand or graveyard. I believe this doesn't need to be said but ALWAYS leave at least one of each Adamancipator Crystal monster in the graveyard so you can utilize the Synchro monsters' second effects and you'll have the recycling effects of the Crystal monsters if its needed. The other extra deck monsters are situational cards or just because I think the look cool (The Red Dragon cards). Generally the deck is consistent enough for the first strategy to fire quickly and fast enough to not be in those situations. Major weaknesses are cards that prevent Special summoning, Search prevention, and banishing. Edit: So I took out some cards out of the extra and add different ones. So the main change is that Old Entity Hastorr has been added. This was to make Red Supernova Dragon viable. However, Supernova is still tricky to get out. So summoning Supernova is mostly gimmicky but is doable, and if your starting hand is Doki Doki, Analyzer, Researcher x2, or Seeker x2, or one of each, and Adamancipator Signs. If you go first summon Doki Doki and use his effect discarding Analyzer to summon another one from your deck. then use Researcher's and/or Seeker's effect to special summon themselves. You could use the second effect of Researcher and/or Seeker to excavate. Then synchro summon Old Entity Hastorr using Doki Doki and which ever tuner you used to excavate. Then use Adamancipator Signs to bring back the Turner you used to summon Hastorr. Then Syncrho summon for Red Supernova Dragon. Then Enjoy your 6000 (due to having 4 tuners in the graveyard) destruction immune beat stick. If you go Second just do the same thing.

deck_excerpt: A Dinosaur deck featuring the "Jurrac" archetype, fiery Dinos who try to lower the opposing life points through sheer force and using the various tool
deck_description:
This is my take at building a "Jurrac" deck. The "Jurrac" is from way back during the Duel Terminal/Hidden Arsenal era and, even though it pains me to say that, their overall age shows in the power level of the cardboard in question. The archetype itself is consisting entirely of Fire Dinosaur monsters, who (except for some rare cases) do not manage to get over 1700 ATK without a tribute or Extra Deck access and try to lower the opposing life points over the course of multiple turns, since they will most likely not have enough fighting power to OTK to opponent. They also focus on fighting monsters and various members of the archetype profit from destroying opposing monsters in form of being able to use various effects. But despite their shortcomings, they can be used as an effective albeit slow beatdown deck that is easy to play and has some fun plays up its sleeve.

The "Jurrac" part of the deck is three copies of "Jurrac Aeolo", your Level 1 tuner and a "Circle of the Fire Kings" on legs exclusively for "Jurracs", three copies of "Jurrac Guaiba", since it is the most used and useful beater who Special summons other "Jurracs" when destroying monsters in battle, two "Jurrac Monoloph" who can be cloggy due to the low ATK of 1500 but can become a "Raigeki" in monster form with ATK boosts or "Moon Mirror Shield" and two "Jurrac Velo" and "Jurrac Dino" respectively, who are both not that useful but one can potentially still fetch monsters while the other is a Level 3 Tuner monster.

Help for the deck comes in form of various other Dinosaur monsters. "Ultimate Conductor Tyranno" is really good in any Dinosaur-based deck, which high stats, easy summoning condition, helpful setup and disruption at Quick Effect-speed. One copy of "Dinowrestler Pankratops" is also Special summonable with high stats and can destroy stuff by tributing a "Dinowrestler" monster, which in this deck is even possible without "Dinowrestler Pankratops" killing itself due to the Special summonable Level 2 Tuner "Dinowrestler Coelasilat". Two copies of "Souleating Oviraptor" are both setup and search, while I personally like "Miscellaneousaurus" at three, since it not only protects your board but can also just banish itself from the graveyard during your turn to Special summon an "Jurrac Aeolo" from your deck at no additional cost.

The Spells and Traps are mostly for consistency and ATK manipulation. On the consistency side of things, we have one "Instant Fusion" (as either cheeky removal via "Thousand-Eyes Restrict" or added material for Synchro summons by summoning "Pragtical"), two "Pot of Desires" (since card draw is important and this is the best option to play in this deck since you will miss none of the cards if they are removed), a copy of "One for One" (easy "Jurrac Aeolo" search, who can then either be used for Extra Deck summons or to revive a "Jurrac" monster from the graveyard, possibly even the one you discarded as cost), two "Fossil Dig" (Dinosaur searcher) and one "Foolish Burial" (as setup for "Jurrac Aeolo", "Miscellaneousaurus" or "Ultimate Conductor Tyranno") . On the ATK manipulation side, we have "Lost World" (protection for your Dinosaur monsters, easy monster summoning to the opponent's side of the field for later battle destruction and ATK decrease for pretty much every your opponent is going to play), two "Rocket Hand" (ATK booster with added removal) and two "Rising Fire" (slightly weaker "Monster Reborn" effect, but adds 500 ATK to the revived monster and banishes something when being destroyed).

The Extra Deck usage is rather situational. There are Link, Xyz and Synchro monsters, which a lot of monster combinations in the deck being able to summon something useful to the field, but due to the nature of the deck, you cannot always go into the same options since you will not have the necessary resources to do so. "Evolzar Laggia" and "Evolzar Dolkka" are really good Stun monsters and relatively easy to summon in this deck, the Link monsters really just cover your bases when the monsters combinations on the field don't allow for anything else ("Hiita the Fire Charmer, Ablaze" as a recovery tool, "Duelittle Chimera" as a stat booster, and the "Knightmare" monsters for graveyard setup and destruction effects). The Synchro line-up consists of "Jurrac Velphito" (kills certain "Marshmallon"-esque monsters if necessary) and "Hi-Speedroid Chanbara" (double attacker which gets more powerful for every attack) for Level 5, "Coral Dragon" for Level 6 (more of a filler, since combinations like "Dinowrestler Coelasilat" and "Souleating Oviraptor" rarely happen, but offers a destruction effect and card draw when destroyed), and "Black Rose Dragon" (board-wipe) and "Jurrac Giganoto" (alternative beatstick) for Level 7. The last two monsters are "Dinowrestler Giga Spinosavate", who plays very well in the deck by aggroing opposing attacks while offering 3000 ATK and a solid set of effects, and "Jurrac Meteor", which is the actual boss monster of the "Jurrac" archetype and offers the same effect as "Black Rose Dragon" for more costs, but summons a "Jurrac" Tuner from your graveyard afterwards. I would only ever go into "Meteor" if the opponent is weak enough to be finished by a 1700 ATK "Jurrac Dino", otherwise it is probably not worth summoning it.

And that is the deck. "Jurracs" are sadly not even close to being a viable archetype, but they are easy to learn and understand, which could make them a nice first deck for beginners. With the added support they should still be able to win a game or two, especially in a more casual and friendly environment. And who knows, maybe there is some support waiting for them in some distant future.

If you want to know more about the "Jurrac" archetype (and other archetypes for that matter), please feel free to visit my blog and my "Jurrac" archetype analysis at: https://cubiccreativity.wordpress.com/2020/05/31/archetype-analysis-jurrac/.

deck_excerpt: Excited Melffy deck with a Tribrigade engine  (And also a reference to Kevin Hart)
deck_description: Well, here's a deck that I never thought would become good: Melffy.   This here is a Tribrigade Melffy deck that uses the latter's newest piece of support, an Xyz Monster called Excited Melffys. Because of that card's name, I decided to name this deck "So Excited!!", after a joke from Kevin Hart's comedy tour "Irresponsible Tour."   The "So Excited!" joke: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TUJVkj2FK00&t=49s   Due to this deck's abundance of hand traps, Lightning Storm, and Dark Ruler No More, you absolutely HAVE to go second. So Excited's strategy is to use whatever cards you have to punish your opponent's plays, then summon a Rank 2 Xyz--most likely Excited Melffys--to battle with, and then use that to summon Negalogia AA-Zeus after it battles. Also, the Tribrigade Monsters and 3 copies of Tenki are there as play extenders.

deck_excerpt: True Draco Dogmatika Shaddoll Eldlich Control 2020 (Going First)
deck_description: Alright so after testing with this deck for a while I figured out how amazing it is, of course made from scratch, I started testing out the ratios and all and this seems to be the near perfect build. The deck wants to go first. It doesn't brick much at all and since it has so many engines built into it the deck has so many recovery plays its insane. By using Nadir Servant to send the Shaddoll engine to the grave to search and recover Shaddoll Schism. And all the Golden Land cards have graveyard effects plus are tribute fodder for the True Draco monsters which is amazing. The engines have so much synergy with each other. Not to mention that sending the True Draco spells and traps using the Golden Lord triggers their effects which is really good. Also, for those who are confused about why Crystron Haqlifibrax is in the extra deck, its because its a Cherry's target since basically every deck is playing it right now. In my opinion using Cherry's to get rid of it makes your opponent at a huge disadvantage especially for those synchro variant decks where they go into Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon with Haqlifibrax and another machine monster... Without Haqlifibrax they'll need some other machine monster(s) to go into full synchro combo. I hope you guys enjoy the deck, and stick around for more!

deck_excerpt: A Magistus deck with Dogmatika shell for turboing out Crusadia Avramax and Savage Dragon.
deck_description: The deck utilizes the new Magistus cards with a Dogmatika shell to abuse Halqifibrax for ending on a Crusadia Avramax (empowered by Masquerena) and Savage Dragon Turn 1 board. It's fairly consistent but suffers from interruptions, which is why the deck is not going to be meta in its current iteration. It's too reliant on Magistus Zoroa (the tuner that allows searching through Artemis, special summon, AND Halqi access) to pull off its shenanigans. That is why the deck does not have enough hand traps; they reduce the consistency with which you can play Zoroa turn 1. Hard draw, summoner monk, Artemis search through Endymion, foolish burial or Crowley + Vritra Magistus—these are the ways for getting to Zoroa.     The strategy is to somehow have Masquerena and Halqi on the field (Zoroa search and special summon helps with this a lot). Your target for Halqi is O-Lion. Then, you get Linkross from Halqi, which will grant you two tokens. Then, link summon Metal Marcher and get a level 3 token plus revive your Zoroa. Then, you can synchro summon Savage from the 2 tokens (3+1) and Zoroa (4). You can summon Crusadia Avramax with Marcher, Masquerena, and Linkross.     If you have an extender plus a Dogmatika in hand or if you have Reborn, you can even summon Halqi a second time for shenanigans during the opponent's turn. For instance, after negating with Savage, you can summon Formula Synchron for a draw, then you can synchro summon using Formula's effect for Stardust Warrior, which will give you a summon negation and a floating effect if it gets removed.     If you have only one extender (like a spare Dogmatika), you can change the play around a bit. With Linkross, just summon 1 token instead of 2. Then, do the combo normally until you get Crusadia Avramax. Afterwards, alongside Avramax, you will have Zoroa, O-lion token, and your extender (Dogmatika for example). Summon your second Halqi with Zoroa and level 4 extender (NOT TOKEN). Then, next turn, summon Wonder Magician with Halqi for S/T pop, after which you can summon Savage dragon with Wonder Magician's effect and your level 3 token. If you want, you can change your ED so that with Halqi, you can summon Desert Locusts into Ravenous Crocodragon. Personally, I prefer getting Savage for negation but in some matches, the card ripping effect of Locusts may become relevant.     Overall, the deck is obviously not going to compete with the meta decks, because of its vulnerability to interruptions. Also, because it has a hard time going second due to the lack of hand traps. However, it's a really fun deck to pilot because of the complexity and the satisfaction of beating opponents down with Avramax.     Please feel free to suggest edits, both for the Main Deck and the ED/SD.

deck_excerpt: An optimal way for Muskets to go first and gain advantage.
deck_description: This relies on using Black Garden to flood your opponent's field with tokens, then summoning Max to search 2 musket spells/traps. You would activate Black Garden, then normal summon a musket. That would then trigger Black Garden to give your opponent a token. Once you do that, you can go into Max. Due to how the chain works, you can have Black Garden be Chain Link 2 to give your opponent the token, then use Max effect to search 2. The only problem with this strategy is that it leaves Max somewhat vulnerable, so I would recommend playing cards that can restrict your opponent from killing your Max, preferably Mystic Mine, although you could use anything that protects Max from battle. Outside of the musket cards and black garden, you could run essentially whatever other cards you wish for the deck. This build uses eXceed for Bagooska plays in case you either need a floodgate that can help protect Max if you don't have access to Mine and Extravagance adds needed draw power to a deck that needs it. If you can't afford Extravagance, you could play Desires instead and doing so could also allow you to have a more open extra deck while also allowing some musket effects to go off. Do keep in mind that banishing the targets for Max does suck, so be careful with that. It isn't a perfect list by far, but I think it does add a going first option for Muskets that I felt like they lacked. If there is any advice you could give me, that would be great. I hope you enjoy the build and have fun! :)

deck_excerpt: This could be considered a "Armed Dragon" or an "Armed Dragon Thunder" Deck, but its only using Armed Dragon Thunder LV 3 and Armed Dragon Flash as a
deck_description: This is a combo deck so it goes first. My first thought about the Armed Dragon Thunder monsters were that "Holy crap, this is so good (for a retrain)." We are using Armed Dragon Thunder LV 3 and Armed Dragon Flash as a Rokket Quick Launch substitute with LV 3 being more card advantage if it is discarded. This deck (from what I got out of testing) can make at least 2 negates and some large bodies (I'm not the best combo player so don't take my word for it; a good combo player can find ways to make more negates). This deck needs grave set-up early game to have some revival effects be used. Dragunity Remus, Dragon Shrine, Dragon Ravine, and Cards of Consonance allow for this. Possible starters for this deck include any of the effects that activate upon a normal summon. These include Dragunity Aklys, Dragunity Dux, Dragunity Guisarme, or Armed Dragon Flash (to get to Romulus or Guardragons). Your follow-up is using Dragunity Arma Mystletainn to get a possible Synchro material and a Dragunity Tuner from when it specials after being equipped. Dragunity Divine Lance does the same thing by equipping a Dragunity tuner from the deck. Extenders include literally any non-opt summon from spell/trap zone Dragunity Tuner, Dragunity Arma Gram, Dragunity Remus, and Dragunity Legatus. These special summon themselves for you to get extra link or synchro material. Dragunity Knight - Barcha is a great extender, but it's difficult to make once you get deep into your Guardragon combo since it needs Winged Beasts. Searchers include Dragunity Glow, Dragon Ravine, Dragunity Knight - Romulus, and Dragunity Divine Lance. Extra Deck includes Dragunity Knight - Vajrayana which is a decent option instead of Barcha, but it's only here if you can't make Barcha. Dragunity Knight - Luin is the better option than Vajrayana if you can make it. Dragunity Knight - Gae Dearg is a searcher and grave set-up. Dragunity Knight - Barcha is the best play extender, but is hard to make after your Guardragon combo. Dragunity Knight - Ascalon is a potential removal option going second, but is a way better floater going first. Dragunity Knight - Areadbhair is one of your negates and a Heavy Storm when destroyed. Borreload Savage because it's an omni-negate, but it does not destroy (WTF???). Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon is another negate and is an okay choice of negation in this format. Borrelsword Dragon is for going second big brrrrrr damage. Saryuja is a play extender and another choice for a play extender. Dragunity Knight - Romulus is the major extender in this deck. Hieratic Seal of the Heavenly Spheres is a bounce and a floater. Triple Burst Dragon, Guardragon Pisty, and Guardragon Elpy are for your Guardragon Combo. Side Deck has Koa'ki Meru Drago for prevention of Golden Lord, Borreload Savage, Borrelsword, and Chaos Dragons(?). Dragunity of the Hurricane is for going second or playing on your opponent's turn. Cosmic is for more backrow removal. Called By the Grave is here if you go against a handtrap-ccentric deck. Infinite Impermanence for the negations. I really want to make an Armed Dragon Thunder deck, but I'm still thinking of a possible engine to put in instead of just simply Guardragons.

deck_excerpt: A little try to make the legendary fisherman a little bit more playable with the crystal girl support
deck_description: In this new deck I'm trying to create a semi-viable way to summon the legendary fisherman into the field, using the effect of the crystal girl, it allows you to draw a lvl5+ WATER monster from the deck at the end phase, so the best way to use it is by tributing it with one of the mermails, abyssmegalo or abyssteus, or with citadel whale if the crystal girl is on the field, so in the end face yo can bring the legendary fisherman (I or II) and in your next turn if you have a lvl5+ water monster on your field you can spc.summon her again from the graveyard, activating her effect and allowing you to bring the legendary fisherman III, if the crystal girl is not on your first hand but you have, deep sea diva, you can activate her effect, bring neptabyss, then tribute atlantean dragoon, and bring another atlantean dragoon, with the dragoon bring abyssmegalo or the lappis dragon and special summon them, and after that you can use the deep sea diva and the neptabyss to bring abyssalacia from the extra deck, this card will allow you to:  a) if you have dragoons, marksman, or infantry in your hand, use them in the enemy turn for, search one sea serpent, or destroy a set card on the opponent field, or destroy a face up card on the opponent field, also bring one mermail in add to your hand that could be abyssteus  b)if this card is destroyed and sent to the graveyard by your opponent effect or cause your opponent destroy it in battle, you can throw one water monster from your deck to the graveyard and then special summon one water monster from the graveyard, yo can use this for throw the crystal girl and bring it from the graveyard for activate her effect in the turn of the enemy, or if you have the field bring the citadel whale and since it was special summoned you can bring the sea stealth attack from the deck to the field, or if you have the legendary  fisherman III in your hand, use her for bring the legendary fisherman II  I heard some of your recommendations, so i made the deck a little bit small reducing some non very important cards and also i add some more synchro in the deck that could be more useful in more situations

deck_excerpt: New(ish) routing, making Calamities + Savage into a 1 card combo.
deck_description: So, I worked on my combo a little bit further, incorporating Power Tool Dragon, and trying to find Anti-Nibiru combos that worked with it, and here's where I'm at. Instead of making a level 5 ressing an Infernoble monster, I'm opting to make Cryston Quandax. However, rather than just enabling a path to True King of All Calamities, I've made the board Savage + Crocodragon + Charles, with Savage + Charles as reasonably anti-nibiru combo when you have access to Gearfried, by summoning the Plaguespreader off of Halqifibrax, and using Cryston Quandax + a level 4 to make Power Tool Dragon to ressurect it.  For those unfamiliar with the deck, Infernoble is a combo deck, which has a gameplan largely resolving around using Infernoble Emperor Charles in combination with Smoke Grenade of the Thief to be a big boss monster (with potentially good protection) that pulls cards out of your hand, and protects this with negates. These are generally Isolde turbo decks, that aim to take advantage of all the good combo cards available in the format. This particular version can turn 1 Isolde into True King of All Calamities + a Borreload Savage Dragon (Or Crocodragon + Charles, useful when you pick back up Smoke Grenade to loop hands a second time).  Combo #1 - Bread and Butter  1 - Summon Isolde, add a card to the hand  2 - Isolde effect, send 4 (including Phoenix Blade and Smoke Grenade), summon Armageddon Knight, send Plaguespreader Zombie  3 - Link Isolde into Linkross, summon 2 tokens  4 - Put 1 card from your hand on top of your deck - summon Plaguespreader Zombie (don't use Phoenix Blade)  5 - Synchro Zombie + 1 token into Martial Metalmarcher. Since zombie is banished it summons nothing. This feels bad, but making Power Tool a tuner is important.  6 - Synchro Metalmarcher + Arma Knight into Power Tool Dragon, add D.D.R to your hand  7 - Link Power Tool + Linkross into Halqifibrax, summon Deskbot 001  8 - Link Deskbot + Halqifibrax into Auroradon, summon 3 tokens, summon Deskbot from the GY  9 - Synchro Deskbot + the level 1 token + 1 level 3 token into Roland  10 - Auroradon effect, tribute the 2 tokens, summon Mecha Phantom Beast Coltwing, Coltwing effect summon 2 tokens, Deskbot effect summons itself from GY  11 - Synchro Deskbot + 1 token into Herald of the Arc Light  12 - Because of its effect, Coltwing will be a level 7 monster. You can use Phoenix Blade's effect to add itself to your hand, then discard it for D.D.R. which summons Plaguespreader Zombie.  13 - Synchro Plaguespreader Zombie + Coltwing into Charles  14 - Synchro Roland + token into Savage.  This is the combo that you're going to end on a lot of the time, and is the go-to when you know it is safe. It puts the most # of negates on the board, and takes the slightest toll on your hand. It uses up all of your zones, so when you see Gearfried, go for an anti-nibiru combo.  Combo #2 - True King + Negate (or Hand Snipe)  1 - Summon Isolde, add a card to the hand  2 - Isolde effect, send 3 (including Phoenix Blade and Smoke Grenade), summon Crusadia Arboria  3 - Link Isolde into Linkross, summon 2 tokens  4 - Link Linkross + Arboria into Crystron Halqifibrax, summon Plaguespreader Zombie  5 - Synchro Zombie + token into Martial Metalmarcher, summon Arboria  6 - Synchro Arboria + token into Crystron Quandax  7 - You CAN use the Quandax to link into Auroradon, leaving Metalmarcher on the field, and there are combos in the deck that do that, but for this combo, Link Metalmarcher + Needlefibre into Auroradon, summon 3 tokens  8 - Synchro Quandax + token into Power Tool Dragon, add D.D.R to the hand  9 - Auroradon effect, tribute 2 tokens, summon Coltwing, summon 2 tokens  10 - Put on card from you hand into your deck, summon Plaguespreader Zombie (Do no use the Sword!)  11 - Synchro Plaguespreader Zombie + Power Tool Dragon into Charles  12 - Use Phoenix Blade's effect, add it to the hand  13 - Activate D.D.R., discard Phoenix Blade, summon Plaguespreader Zombie  14 - Synchro Plaguespreader + Token into Roland  15 - Summon Plaguespreader Zombie with its effect (you can use Phoenix Blade this time, but you aren't guaranteed the monsters, and often Infernoble monsters are more valuable in the GY)  16 - Since Coltwings effect makes it a level 7, synchro into Ravenous Crocodragon Archethys (you pick back up what you put in your deck)  17 - Synchro Roland + token into Savage  This combo is good for when you know you're going up against a monster mash deck. Adamancipator is the best example of this, but against a lot of decks a True King is just G.G. The other time you'll use this combo is to snipe hands with Crocodragon, for when you see a Smoke Grenade naturally, or can pick one up with Renaud. Here we see the weaknessess and strengths of Plaguespreader Zombie in full effect - it isn't once per turn, but putting cards into the deck is not fun. But if you're feeling the card disadvantage, and you have Smoke Grenade of the Thief in your hand, this is a targeted way to snipe an extra card from their hand, or an extra disruption on their turn. The negate is generally more valuable than this, but it could vary, especially if you snipe hands early and see multiple outs, or think Calamities is good in the matchup. (he has to be more valuable than Charles + an interaction, or the equivalent of 3 interruptions, which is hard)  But what if you want to play Gearfried? Let's face it, Infernoble has many strengths, and Gearfried is one of them. Well, you can start combos with Gearfried pretty easily, any time you see it alongside an equip, or see the right Infernoble cards together, especially since we're running Ingnoble Knight of High Laundsallyn to secure that Renaud + Ogier play. When you do see Gearfried, summon him as normal, and go through the following combo.  Combo #3 - Anti-Nibiru Savage + Charles  1 - Isolde, search a card  2 - Isolde effect, send 4 for Oliver (by now you should realize how important Phoenix Blade and Smoke Grenade are)  3 - Link Isolde into Linkross, summon 2 tokens  4 - Link Oliver + Linkross into Halqifibrax, summon Plaguespreader Zombie  5 - Synchro Plaguespreader Zombie + token into Martial Metalmarcher, summon Oliver  6 - Synchro Oliver + token into Roland (effect)  7 - Link Metalmarcher + Needlefibre into Auroradon, summon 3 tokens  8 - Synchro Oliver + token into Borreload Savage Dragon  9 - Summon Plaguespreader Zombie with its effect, putting a card from your hand into your deck  10 - Tribute Auroradon + token into Coltwing (since you put a card into your deck before this, it could be coltwing). Its effect doesn't activate.  11 - Coltwing is a level 7, so badabing, badaboom, you have Oliver.  12 - You just have an extra token here, so you can make Herald if you have an unused Oliver or Renaud in your hand.  This combo changes by the hour. I've figured out a way to get to Charles + Savage that puts up an extra token, and uses Coltwing, so 1 fewer brick. This combo also goes through Oliver, so better protection on Charles.  I've added in the Tatsunoko and Omega to the main deck, by cutting Ignoble Knight and Isolde. Ignoble Knight is only good for anti-Nibiru combos in this deck, and only for some of them, so I'm fine cutting it, and the back-up Isolde isn't really as good turn 2, or useful if they negate Isolde's second effect. I hate losing Ignoble Knight, but I like having even more hand-looping potential. I've added a second Living Fossil so that we can add a second copy after sending a copy, in case we Monster Reborn or somehow D.D.R a Power Tool Dragon.  Cut the Calamities combo to put back in Ignoble Knight, for more Gearfried starts, as well as Instant Fusion with Invoked Raidjin as an extender. I kept the tutorial in, in case somebody wanted to run the combo. I almost never made Calamities that way anyways, and having extra extenders helps the deck play through interactions. I'm liking 2 Aqua Dolphin, 2 Living Fossil. Aqua Dolphin is a very good normal summon in the deck in its own right, and Living Fossil is a good extender. D.D.R. is similarly not a brick, and can actually extend you through hand traps.  There's definitely some play to these combos. I've found Power Tool is not always necessary to make your ultimate board, but I do like the consistency boost and combo potential it and D.D.R add to the deck.  I'm up to 2 Power Tool Dragon now. Pak is right, it's useful for comboing off through bricks, or for extending combos further. I replaced Instant Fusion with E-Teleport. While this forces you to go through Needlefibre (I'd always rather start with Isolde+Linkross) it also extends into Needlefibre, and even just the Needlefibre combo is pretty sweet. With good play and correct extenders, you can make some pretty insane boards through interruptions while hand looping for multiple cards.

deck_excerpt: Water can still make 1 card Calamities, while hand looping for 3, and it doesn't even take up much space in the extra deck.
deck_description: Basically it's a bunch of 1 and 2 card combos that end on Calamities. One tricky part of the deck is that Moulinglacia NEEDS to be summoned for the combo to work, but the nice thing about this combo is that it leaves plenty of space to play around in the extra deck. On the other hand, other combo decks have been hit pretty hard, and between Deep Sea Minstrel, Triple T, and Moulinglacia it can hand loop for 4 cards while setting up Calamities, which is pretty hard to out.  Deep Sea Diva is full combo, as is Abyssteus + Dragoons, Neptabyss + Moulinglacia, Neptabyss + Dragoons, Deep Sea Minstrel + Dragoons, and a slew of 3 card combos, especially involving Deep Sea Aria.

deck_excerpt: Adamancipator has lost Block Dragon and O-Lion. But so long as Needlefibre exists, degeneracy is possible.
deck_description: So, Block Dragon is gone, and so is O-Lion. What is Adamancipator to do to get onto the board?  Here comes what will certainly be this format's darling for combo players, Karakuri Shogun.  The deck certainly doesn't have Block Dragon anymore. But now instead of your basic Halq combo ending on Raptite + a couple of monsters, it can end on Raptite + Savage/Dragite. The huuuuge downside is that this combo uses up all of your zones, so ideally a Linkross combo will be discovered to replace this, but in the meantime it gives you a chance to actually get on the board with Adamans, without getting lucky on your hits. The other big downside is no Apollousa for you, since Auroradon locks you out of Links, so in all probability, this is just a stop-gap. Having said that, the deck wasn't hit quite as hard as I thought it was.  I lied, you do have exactly 1 monster slot open for Koa'ki Meiru Guardian. That's awesome.

deck_excerpt: 3-axis Synchro adapted for post-Sept banlist
deck_description: Goes into Cherubini, Linkross, Halq, Auroradon plays after the ban of O-lion and Jet Synchron.  The deck basically consists entirely of 3-star starters and extenders to get into Cherubini.  Combo demo:  https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=392223-21399099

deck_excerpt: this deck is just what ive been able to make irl from three stucture decks plus a few cards i already had and some that i was able to buy from my loca
deck_description:
the main combo of the deck you'll find pretty much anywhere if you just look up "shaddoll combo" but ill still describe it here.
  1. using either shaddoll fusion or el shaddoll fusion: summon contruct using either squamata or wendi + trick clown.
  2. (assuming you used squamata) activate the effects of construct, squamata and trick clown. trick clown will summon itself then send both wendi and resh shaddoll incarnation from the deck to the grave using the effects of squamata and construct.
  3. using the effect of wendi in the grave set naelshaddoll ariel from the deck. (if wendi was used as fusion material you will do this in the previous step in place of squamata's effect)
  4. you then link trick clown and construct into cross-sheep. in the grave constructs effect will activate to add the fusion spell you used earlier to you hand.
  5. then you use the effect of resh shaddoll incarnation in the grave, banishing it and construct to flip ariel.
  6. using the effect of ariel you summon construct (from the banished zone) in defence position to a zone cross-sheep points to.
  7. using the effect of contruct send shaddoll schism to the grave (this will be important later) and using the effect of cross-sheep summon trick clown from the grave.
  8.  so at this point you can either summon borrelsword using cross-sheep, ariel and trick clown or you can continue to step 9
  9. link construct and cross-sheep into verte anaconda
  10. using constructs effect add shaddoll schism to your hand
  11. using the effect on verte anaconda copy the effect of el shaddoll fusion then fuse it with any shaddoll monster you have in your hand to make el shaddoll winda.
  12. set schism (if you want, make shekinaga on your opponent's turn using cross sheep and any other shaddoll monster in your grave which will give you a negate if you have a shaddoll card in hand)
so thats the combo, you never actually normal summon in this so at any point you need to, you can still normal summon.

deck_excerpt: Pretty standard invoked Dogmatika build with a few techs.
deck_description: This deck has been very consistent but I feel like it could still be better. First start is mainly about getting mechaba and an ecclesia out so you can start searching dogs while still having a negate. Ideally want to get shaddoll schism first turn so you can go into winda on your opponents turn. If your board is still intact after the second turn it is pretty easy to go into invoker of madness or BLS. Plenty of hand traps for going second. I like playing three knighted because you can actually throw it out there on your opponents first turn so if you have another in your hand you already have a negate set up or it sets your field to go into invoker of maddness next turn by linking something into almiraj. Anyway, any feedback would be much appreciated, and thanks for taking a look!     Also looking for advice on side deck options if you cannot tell!

deck_excerpt: Man-Eater bug Beatdown deck that can even stand up to full power sky strikers somehow if youre lucky
deck_description: Man-Eater bug is an incredibly powerful card that gives you access to a powerful rank 2 engine in the form of normal summoning 2 Man-Eater bugs, as well as nontargeting destruction.  Try to sit on card advantage with desires if you open it, or mystic mine/mirror force if you didn't. Use Man-Eater bug, along with the rest of the powerful flip effect destruction cards, to stall until you draw out to cards.  If you can summon 2 LVL 8 monsters then you can go into Draglubion, summoning hope harbinger and equipping tachyon eyes for control, or vice versa for otks. You could also go into Dingirsu and climb into the Seven Sins, claiming a free field banish and a 4000ATK beater with protection. The deck also has Number 27 if you can get LVL 4s on the field, which can go into the big train cards. You might want to add a rank 4 engine for this.  Waking the dragon is a power card that you can summon Avramax, Dragoon, or Ultimate Falcon off of depending on the situation and deck. You can also summon Man-Eater bug off of it.  Use moon mirror shield to beatdown the opponent  help

deck_excerpt: Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon is the heart of this deck, composed with powerful Dark Magician support cards.
deck_description:
Strategy 1: 
  1. Activate Magicians' Souls to send Dark Magician Girl to the GY.
  2. Special Summon Magicians' Souls.
  3. Normal Summon Magician's Rod to search for Soul Servant.
  4. Link Summon into Predaplant Verte Anaconda
  5. Activate Special Ability of Predaplant Verte Anaconda to send Red-Eyes Fusion to GY, along with Dark Magician and Red-Eyes Black Dragon.
  6. This will result in the special summoning of Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon.
  7. Use Soul Servant to place Dark Magician related card on top of deck.
  8. Banish Soul Servant to draw 2 cards (since Dark Magician Girl and Dark Magician are in GY).
Strategy 2:
  1. Normal Summon Keeper of Dragon Magic.
  2. Activate Special Ability of Keeper of Dragon Magic (to discard Dark Magician in order to search for Polymerization).
  3. Activate second Special Ability of Keeper of Dragon Magic (reveal Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon to special summon Dark Magician in face-down defense position).
  4. Use Polymerization to fusion summon Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon.
Strategy 3: 
  1. Activate Dark Magical Circle.
  2. Follow Strategy 2, but summon Dark Magician the Dragon Knight instead of Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon.
  3. Set Eternal Soul.
  4. With these 3 cards, you should be able to banish a card from your opponent every turn, in a tough-to-beat loop!

deck_excerpt: Eldlich Synchro is back baby, and it ain't dying any time soon. *New and improved combo*
deck_description: There are ways that this combo is not as good as the Jet combo. Plaguespreader Zombie forcing you to put a card back on top of the deck is much worse than discarding, especially in Edlich, and you have to run a lot more bricks. It also doesn't leave a lot of room to play around with, you're basically just running Eldlich cards and a zombie synchro combo with hand traps. On the other hand, you only have to run 1 of each brick, since Zombie lets you put them back into your deck, and Uni-Zombie is an incredible starter option in Eldlich, since it can discard Eldlich cards for free while sending Plaguespread, and vice versa.  Sorry combo doesn't work, took out the one that did. Wish you could take these down.

deck_excerpt: Sky Striker decklist after september banlist for at least regional level play.
deck_description: Decks main win con is getting to accescode talker while your opponent has 5000 or less life points.  This is achieved through control with hand traps and, hate to say this, Mystic Mine  Sky striker cards are exceptional when going second through popping your opponents monsters and backrow with afterburners, and negating and stealing your opponents monsters.  Hand trap lineup is extremely flexible although I effect veilers are mandatory as a 2-of at least.  Book of Moon is there to provide some first turn plays by shutting off your opponents synchro and link plays, and forcing out negations and reactions going second.  Instead of Triple Tactics Talent you can easily play with either 3 Pot of desires or (my favorite) 1 Averice and 2 desires. Arguably it could be better to ditch TTT since it hardly does anything for Sky Strikers going first.  Forbidden droplet can be switched for Dark Ruler No More or Evenly Matched depending on the meta at your locals or regionals.

deck_excerpt: A "Hazy Flame" deck, which primarily summons Level 6 monsters to access the Rank 6 Xyz toolbox.
deck_description:
This is my take at building a "Hazy Flame" deck. They piqued my interest during the "Create-a-card" contest Konami is still holding at the time of writing this. The archetype, unfortunately, did not manage to get out of the first round, but it certainly sparked some interest in people. "Hazy Flame" is an archetype that consists entirely of Level 6 Fire monster with their unique shared effect being that they all cannot be targeted by the opposing card effects. The goal is to summon multiple of those Level 6 monsters to summon various Rank 6 Xyz monsters and win the game using the effects of your assembled Extra Deck force.

The combination of needing both Level 6 and the Fire Attribute is fairly restrictive, meaning that you will have to stay in the archetype to gain access the Extra Deck. But thankfully, there are some options to work with on that end. "Hazy Flame Peryton" is your main playstarter and can be Normal summoned via "Hazy Pillar" without tribute, who can Special summon two "Hazy Flames" by tributing itself and discarding another Fire monster. This allows you to search for any combination of "Hazy Flame" monsters, but an especially useful combo is picking double "Hazy Flame Hydra", which locks you into summoning Fire monsters but not only can be used to summon the very powerful "Evolzar Solda", but also give whatever monster you Xyz summon using them additional Xyz materials from the graveyard (which you already setup via the effect of "Hazy Flame Peryton").

"Hazy Flame Griffin" can be Special summoned from the hand if your opponent controls a monster and if everything in your graveyard and on your board is Fire Attribute, but can also be cheated out via "Fire King Island". "Hazy Flame Cerbereus" has a handy effect to Normal summon itself without tribute and is your main searcher in the deck who is triggered by being destroyed; something that both "Fire King Island" and "Goka, the Pyre of Malice" happily do for it. "Fire King Island" can even destroy it in hand and therefore allows you to access the first combo I named without losing the Normal Summon slot to "Hazy Flame Cerbereus". "Hazy Flame Sphynx" has no summon help itself, but can potentially fetch a monster by guessing the top card of your deck correctly (since the deck is mostly monsters, I would suggest guessing that most of the time).

Further summoning options in the deck are "Rekindling", since "Hazy Flame Hydra", "Hazy Flame Cerbereus" and "Hazy Flame Hyppogrif" have 200 DEF. This is also the only reason why "Hazy Flame Hyppogrif" is in the deck at one copy. "Fire King Arvata" is the searchable card for "Fire King Island" and provides effect negation in addition to being a more summonable monster if you cannot access anything else. "Evoltile Megachirella" might seem weird, but it can trade itself against "Hazy Flame Hydra" with relative ease while also potentially refueling "Evolzar Solda". "Hieratic Dragon of Tefnuit" is not a Fire monster, but can Special summon itself if the opponent controls a monster and also fetches the single copy of "Tyhone #2" when being used as tribute, which together with "Hazy Flame Peryton" and "Hazy Flame Hydra" could summon your boss monster at maximum power with five materials.

The backrow was mostly mentioned already: "Fire King Island" and "Hazy Pillar" are there for consistency reasons, while "Rekindling" not only has the task of providing Xyz material but also could accrue a full board of ~2000 ATK monster, which can be used for a surprising beatdown strategy. "One for One" searches for "Evoltile Megachirella" (albeit this way of accessing "Hazy Flame Hydra" will cost quite a few hand cards), "Monster Reborn" is the usual graveyard summoning tool while "Foolish Burial" allows for graveyard setup. The two "Hieratic Seal of Convocation" allow for the search of "Hieratic Dragon of Tefnuit" and further boost the otherwise weak consistency and "Celestial Observatory" can add copies of "Hazy Flame Hydra" or other monsters you potentially do not need in the hand to the deck and refreshes your hand.

Since I already mentioned the boss monster: "Hazy Flame Basiltrice" was (and still is) the main goal to summon in "Hazy Flame". This fiery chicken has sizeable stats, a banish effect and added protection at five materials, but sadly dies rather easily to "Kaijus". Other than that, the Extra Deck is filled with a variety of options to go into in certain situations: "Number 39: Utopia Beyond" supports the beatdown strategy by lowering the opposing monster line-up to zero attack, "Constellar Ptolemy M7" bounces monsters you can not destroy, "Photon Strike Bounzer" is a potential turn one play which can block opposing monster effects, "Number 6: Chronomaly Atlantis" is just a beatstick, "Jinzo - Layered" is a "Crackdown" on legs and therefore steals opposing monsters/defenses and "Fairy Knight Ingunar" bounces the entire field except himself. "Evolzar Solda" was already mentioned, but it is probably the best control option you can get on the field turn one and, since you normally use "Hazy Flame Hydra" to summon it, will have four materials attached to it instead of the usual two. The Link options mostly stay untouched, but "Duelittle Chimera" can be useful for the aforementioned "Rekindling" beatdown while they all serve as easy options to go into if you do not have any better options to go into with the "Rekindling" resources (since those monsters are banished at the end of the turn).

So much for the strategy. I have to add that "Hazy Flame" is pretty bricky due to the usage of Level 6 monsters and being without any good Attribute support cards to boost their consistency (since Fire does not provide much helpful generic support). The deck can be stopped with relative ease if the opponent can throw a negate into your plays and there will be times in which your starting hand does not provide any playable solutions at all. Also, the archetype has problems with doing anything other than putting some Xyz monsters on the field (not unlike the "Battleguards", which do essentially the same but with Rank 5 Xyz). All of these things are good reasons for Konami to re-visit the archetype in the future with some support.

If you are interested to read more about the "Hazy Flame" archetype (or various other archetypes), feel free to visit my blog via the link here: https://cubiccreativity.wordpress.com/2020/09/13/archetype-analysis-hazy-flame/

deck_excerpt: Cyber Dragon
deck_description: Update: I did some adaptations to the banlist (Play "Maxx "C" " as play set in masterduel)  The Idea from this deck is to run over your oponent in one turn. With Infinity, Sieger and the Borel Dragons you have some back role, if you can't finish the game in one turn. Power Bond doubles the ATK of the summoned monster but inflict damage to you based on the original ATK by the summoned monster. In the best case you summon Cyber Twin Dragon with it. It has 5600 ATK with two attacks. Sieger helps you surviving by it's effect. Infinity is a very good interupt and it's effect is once per copy, so you can use multiple Infinitys. I added Yata to the decklist. The reason is very simple. If you normal summon "Cyber Dragon Core" to use it's effekt, you can't use the effect of e.g. "Cyber Dragon Drei". Also it's just lv 2. Yata allows you to tribute Core and specail summon Yata instead. Yata is Lv 5 and a good way to go for Infinity, if necessary. Cyber Load Fusion and Cybernetic Overflow has a very good synergy. You have some hand traps to stop your opponent making plays and Called by the Grave to avoid hand traps. The combopotential is very hughe so you should take some time and test around. But always remember: This decks wants to kill your oponent in the first turn you can attack.

deck_name: Draitron Invoked (Updated with a New Combo)
deck_excerpt: A Draitron Ritual deck that can summon a variety of ritual monsters over many turns by recurring your engine and can fall back on invoked.
deck_description:
===Standard Ritual Combo=== The new ritual combo is quite consistent with full combo being 3 cards and half combo being 2 (half combo ends on 3 neg apollousa and a remaining draitron while full combo gets 3 neg apollousa and a ritual , normally DRA). with this hand you would: Activate fafnir, search for Nova. (to get into your other draitrons)                                                                                  Activate nova and summon alpha from the deck, then link off alpha into linkuriboh                                                  Activate cyber emergency, search for zeta, then activate alphas effect pitching zeta and searching for cyber angel benten.                                                                                                                                                                          Now you have a level 1 on the field, you can activate where arf thou and search for delta                                          Activate Zeta and send delta to search for your ritual spell                                                                                                Then activate gamma and send benten, special summon delta using gammas eff and search for diviner of the herald off of benten's eff Moving on to the second part of the combo: Normal summon diviner of the heralds and send herald of the arc light to the GY, then search for the ritual you want to summon (normally DRA)                                                                                                                             Link off linkuriboh and diviner of the heralds to summon halqifibrax, which goes into PSY-gamma (DON'T ACTIVATE FAFNIR IN RESPONSE TO PSY-GAMMAS SUMMON IT'LL STOP THE COMBO)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Use PSY-gamma and delta to summon metalmarcher, and resummon gamma                                                            Now use halqifibrax, PSY-gamma, metalmarcher and one of your draitrons to summmon 4 neg apollousa  (the normal combo doesnt go into delta i was just very lucky so you would go into 3 neg apollousa and spare the other draitron)                                                                                                                                                                              Activate delta's eff in the GY to send DRA and summon itself, you can then reveal your ritual spell and draw 1   Now you can activate your ritual spell and summon DRA from the GY using gamma and alpha                               Recur your ritual spell by lowering the attack of zeta then resummon linkuriboh.   ===Follow-Up Plays=== In your next turns you can load up your graveyard with more ritual monsters to easily summon using the engine you've developed, these plays can do a lot of different things depending on what the board state is like By summoning alpha from the grave using its eff and sending your summoned ritual monster (or rituals or draitrons you've used for turn) you can search for a ritual monster (take your pick). You can send that searched ritual to grave to summon gamma which can resummon another one of your draitrons. then you can use your ritual spell to go into any of your rituals and if you need to you can recur it the same turn and summon two rituals (although this normally requires you to draw into a draitron for turn). Rinse and repeat to keep building up your board. Additionally during your follow-up turns or your first turn if you can't go into standard combo, you can go through your invoked plays for extra bodies and mechaba interuption. ===Invoked combo=== The invoked combo is fairly simple, normal summon aleister to search invocation, link off aleister into almiraj and then into secure gardna. Use aleister and secure gardna to summon mechaba then recycle aleister for next turn. Then next turn you can use almiraj in the GY to summon purgatrio or if mechaba was outed you can use mechaba in GY to summon another one.   ===Other Plays=== By searching and sending Cyber angel natasha during your follow-up plays (or first turn if you draw into it) you can banish your benten from the grave to summon natasha and take control of one of your opponents monsters, then natasha can give you some free life points (always nice to have especially if you used where arf thou) If you have sauravis you can ritual summon it off of 2 draitrons (one with 1000 less ATK from recurring meteornis) which so you can negate one of your opponents special summons by bouncing sauravis to your hand, by discarding sauravis you can negate an effect from your opponent which targets. (sauravis is normally going to be sided out because its quite situational but if you want to take it out the main deck completely feel free to do so, i haven't had a change to evaluate it much) If your opponent manages to deal with your board, and you can get out 2 of your draitron monsters, you can easily go into Negalogia AA Zeus via Lyrilusc to wipe the board and get a big beater on the board I've also thrown in Masquerena and unicorn for some extra interruption as well as borrelsword if thats your thing. ===Side Deck=== The side deck in this decklist is more for other plays and mini combos you can run (you could even side the 6 card invoked engine instead of maining it) The Nekroz monsters provide powerful going first and second effects which are great at dealing with your opponent. (I havent really played much nekroz so there may be other cards that would work in the deck better than these ones) If you want to you can run waking the dragon to summon out powerful extra deck monsters without much effort (doesn't really work here because i don't run any traps so just swap it out for generic side deck cards if you want to)   ===Other Notes=== I don't play linkross or the V.F.D synchro package because i don't personally like them and i find them to be very O.P and quite toxic, but thats just me.                                                                                                                           I didn't run dragoon cuz my friends bully me for always playing it.   ===Updated===
  • Added Invoked Augoeides for more options with the invoked engine
  • Fixed the startegy guide so its readable
  • Increased the size of the Draitron Package for better Consistency
  If you've read this your probably intrigued by this deck so please give it a like and share it so i have something to brag about i guess

deck_excerpt: Semi-inexpensive Synchro/Fusion Amazoness deck.
deck_description: Just a general Amazoness beatdown deck with a couple small engines, namely a small red-eyes fusion engine and generic synchro engine. It's somewhat synchro based, but the fusion aspect of Amazoness is still there. I tried to keep overly expensive cards out of the deck, but couldn't get it as cheap as I would have originally liked. Some of the cards are pretty expensive; mainly the Knightmare Links, Red-Eyes Darkness Dragoon, the Predaplant link, and Crystron Halqifibrax. The deck will cost around 200 dollars USD, but that's mainly due to the engines. Garden Rose Maiden is a nice side deck option but is not necessary especially when considering her price.
