deck_excerpt: Harpies Rogue?
deck_description: Updated deck with the release of Feather Duster. Feather Duster itself is situational, but the combos in this deck can shut down any deck. Feather Storm is the best card in this deck, able to completely shut down hand traps and opponent's big boards in one card. Going first is always optimal. The board is made the moment you're able to get any 4 harpies on the board. Then you go into this combo for Infinite Negates: Link 2 into Romulus Search and Equip Lance Equip and Summon Phalanx Link Harpie and Phalanx into Union Carrier Link Romulus and Final Harpie into Simorgh Equip Simorgh with Thunderbird via Carrier Summon Avian in End phase via Simorgh  If you go 2nd, then you want to make a board aiming for Aggressive plays dependent on opponents board: Heavy Backrow: Search for Hunting Grounds and start popping backrow. Dragun: Bait out negate from Dragun then drop feather storm from hand with normal summoned harpie. Then go into Zerofyne to wipe effects Golden Lord/Infernobles: Use Cyber Slash to bounce to hand/Extra Deck rather than send to GY.

deck_name: Phantom Thieves of Time [Post Phantom Rage] - Time Thief PK
deck_excerpt: Supported by Danger! and Phantom Knight buddies new and old, behold a DARK Xyz deck that clicks with your mind and boggles your opponent's.
deck_description:
Your man ChupiTrooper's gone and done it again. A new set, a new Time Thief-related deck, and a new outlook on things to come. I dunno what's gotten into me or what has me so attached to these win-pilfering boogers, but I wouldn't have it any other way. So what's new? Well, I'd say a good bit. For one, Phantom Rage is on its way to grace us with new support for practically any DARK Xyz build (basically my immediate thought when seeing the list was "Indirect Time Thief support"). For another, Rusty Bardiche is FINALLY playable again after the madness that was early Orcust decks, although it came at the cost of two CBtG's and freedom from Harpie's Feather Duster. And for a final, I'd say along with my new experience and outlook in life in general, so too has mine towards these guys become. Without further ado, here it is. My latest Time Thief build, with friends new and old to really push them to the next level. Capable of card-snatching, non-targeting bounceback, and a way of using Traps that just really, really tends to get me. We'll go in order of archetypes this time, to really go over each component of the deck and their roles in what we aim to do; pop off with these bad boys by messing with heads and firing back if our foe tries anything nasty.

Time Thieves

These are the handsome devils debuting in Savage Strike the OCG was starved for quite a bit, but then they starved all ten of us players of it back with another key Xyz support monster until Ignition Assault. Fortunately that conflict's come and gone, and now it's time for them to get to work with some fellow DARK monsters of all walks of life. As follows are the Doctor Who, Persona 5, whatever kind of lookalikes you think them to be dorks in full.
  • Who's a good boy? It's Time Thief Regulator, the first of our pilferers and a key one at that. Bringing him out while you have a barren field allows you to Tribute him so he can fetch two of his fellow Time Thieves with different names from the deck. Beware of the looming Ash Blossom, Ghost Ogre, and Effect Veiler however, because if any of these come this pooch's way, your heist is bound to end in seconds. But fret not, we run a certain tribe of beasts as a backup plan.
  • What's a dog without his trainer? The aforementioned Regulator is best friend to our next main three-of, Time Thief Winder. Summoning him in any way will do for his effect well, which adds any Time Thief card other than himself from deck to hand. What you search for may depend on what's already in your hand or GY. Speaking of hands, he can summon himself from the hand just by detaching a material from an Xyz monster you control, so Xyz Summoning just before bringing him out is a good application as well.
  • The Time Thieves are nothing without their technological know-how and doodads, one of which happens to be the Time Thief Bezel Ship. More often than not you'll want to try and get it in the GY for when your Xyz monsters hit the field, because it can then revive itself by detaching a material from one of them, though you'll want to use it for an Xyz Summon immediately after as removing it from the field without doing so will banish it. Hence why a summon of an Xyz monster, detaching Bezel Ship with a Winder in hand, then reviving Bezel Ship by detaching the remaining material is A-OK. Alternatively, its on-field effect is great during your opponent's turn, where it Tributes itself to snatch a card from your opponent's GY and attaches it to Time Thief Xyz monster you control. It's much more useful than you think, actually. It's a Quick Effect for one, so it can be chained to pretty much anything, and your opponent can't use what's no longer in their GY. Try it out for yourself and you'll see what I mean!
  • Though maybe not always as considered, Time Thief Chronocorder can put in some good work like its fellow tools of the trade. When your Xyz monster leaves the field by a card effect (including a certain boss's own), it revives itself from the GY with the same "don't not use me for another Xyz or I'm history" syndrome as Bezel Ship, though this one can Tribute itself as a one-time reflection of battle damage your opponent tries to inflict on you for a turn. Its revival effect, however, is definitely at the forefront, and really just goes to show how recursive these guys can be.
 
  • The leader at the helm is none other than Time Thief Redoer, famous for snatching opponents' cards in the Standby and being very, very hard to kill in the right hands. Depending on what you detach from him (Monster, Spell, or Trap), he'll bounce himself out until the End Phase to dodge attacks and disruptive effects, net you a free draw, or bounce back your opponent's face-up card without even needing to target. Pilot him wisely, as he's about as good as the one who brought him to the field in the first place.
  • The main man's lovely assistant is Time Thief Perpetua, who does her whole team a lot of favors. In Standby, she detaches a card to revive any Time Thief in the GY, including Redoer! Though if you ask me, you'll likely want to get Bezel Ship back out on your opponent's turn for more snatching and Winder on your turn for more searching if Redoer is already up and running. Other than that, she has a Quick Effect at any time to attach a Time Thief card from deck to any of your Xyz monsters, effectively reloading their resources. I urge you not to sleep on this card, given all it can do.
 
  • We've spoken about Time Thief tools of trade before, but what about backrow? Those are just as important! The first of which is Time Thief Flyback. On field it attaches a Time Thief card from deck to your Redoer or Perpetua as material (most often another Flyback), but it can also banish itself from GY to play Bezel Ship's snatching game. That being said, it's not the end of the world if your opponent pops this card, so make them pay by swiping one of their GY resources!
  • Speaking of backrow, nobody likes to be on the receiving end of the kind that really, really doesn't want you to play through your setups. But hey, that's why we run Time Thief Retrograde, which uses Redoer or Perpetua's mere presence to negate a Spell or Trap and attach it to them as material. If it's a Trap that Redoer happens to snatch, you pretty much kill two birds with one stone, since you get to do his bounceback effect immediately after.

Phantom Knights

Those of you that have seen ARC-V (I sure haven't, one way or another) may remember a certain chap named Yuto who piloted these steely specters. Others may remember their signature Link monster as a splash into another kind of deck that took all its competition by storm some time ago, prior to some of its most important tools getting hit on the banlist. Now that Bardiche has atoned for Orcust's sins, it's time to welcome him back into the limelight with a new set of friends to help accomplish what he sets out to. A quick note before starting: these DARK Warriors are VERY recursive and easy to make good Extra Deck material out of or search with. It goes without saying that just like all the other Main Deck monsters, they're very thankful to have Armageddon Knight by their side so their GY shenanigans can take place. Though the same goes for their Spells and Traps, some of which banish themselves to revive their users.
  • It goes without saying that The Phantom Knights of Silent Boots is quite the staple to run at three. From the hand, he can summon himself for free provided you control a fellow Knight of his. This includes a monster or backrow unit, but other than that he banishes himself from the GY to search for a "Phantom Knights" Spell or Trap, just in case you can't set it just yet using the archetype's Link boss. So try Normal Summoning another PK and then this guy from your hand, I promise it'll be worthwhile.
  • Silent Boots' usual partner is The Phantom Knights of Ancient Cloak. He swaps his own position on-field to amp up the ATK and DEF of a DARK monster of your choice by 800, but that's only a drop in the bucket in terms of his utility. You'll mainly be using him to search for a card when banished much like Silent Boots, though instead he looks for any "The Phantom Knights" card, including monsters with those words in the title. Just pay very close attention to the word "The" and you'll be fine.
  • In an interesting twist of fate, a new Main Deck recruit for the shady sword-slingers comes in the form of The Phantom Knights of Tear Scale, and boy howdy can he be a team player. While he's on the field, he lets you discard any card (including non-PK's with beneficial effects in the GY) to act as a Foolish Burial or Foolish Burial Goods for a Phantom Knights card of your choosing from deck. In the GY, however, he can be even more useful. If any Phantom Knight card whatsoever is banished from there (for its effect or other such things), he revives himself to provide utility for further Extra Deck summons. So essentially, by banishing one of the two main Traps for PK's to revive one of their monsters, you can revive this card as well and make an instant Rank 3. Just be sure to use him for one of those, because he has the same "banish if it leaves the field" syndrome as some of the Main Deck Time Thieves tend to.
  • One more main deck PK that'll surely extend your plays, The Phantom Knights of Stained Greaves is an odd beast, but superbly useful. Should you summon a fellow PK, he summons himself from hand and gives you the option to amp its level up by one. So just by setting up Brigandine, that's an instant double-bouncing Redoer for free! Alternatively, he banishes himself from the GY to summon a PK friend of his from hand for free, also with the option to amp up its level by one. Always helps to have a RotA or Armageddon Knight handy to get this bad boy up and running with his friends.
 
  • The main Xyz monster for PK's you'll most often go into is The Phantom Knights of Break Sword. And I gotta say, for a Rank 3 he puts in some serious work. His effect lets you pop a card on your field (9/10 times himself for his own second effect) and any card of your choosing from your opponent's field. Popping himself may sound silly, but that actually activates his destruction effect that revives any two Phantom Knight monsters from your GY and increases their Levels by 1, letting you go into yet another Xyz Summon but only locks you into bringing out DARK monsters for the rest of the turn. You'll want to run two just in case, because more destruction and revival simultaneously just goes to show all the more recursion these guys have.
  • Raiders' Knight is another interesting choice. It looks to be a Break Sword retrain, and it definitely counts as both a PK and Raidraptor, though the latter is pretty much the only mention of them you'll find in the deck. Detaching a card from it lets you Rank-Up or Rank-Down the guy by one into a DARK Xyz of your choosing, so likely either Break Sword or another big bungus DARK Xyz monster rolling about soon.
  • But the head honcho of these guys, free from the shackles of Forbidden at last is The Phantom Knights of Rusty Bardiche. Words can't describe how important this guy is, only requiring three generic DARK monsters to bring out and essentially acting as a Foolish Burial or Foolish Burial Goods for any of your PK cards a la Tear Scale, while also being able to set one of its backrow directly from the deck. That, and summoning a DARK Xyz monster of any kind to a zone it points to lets you pop any card on the field, so a RUM Quick-Play Spell during your turn is applicable in this regard! I repeat, do not sleep on this monster.
 
  • Rounding off the backrow or arms these guys take up is The Phantom Knights of Shade Brigandine. It brings itself out as a Level 4 DARK Warrior, allowing for material of a Rank 4 Xyz of your choosing, but it's worth noting that its effect lets you activate it the turn it's set, provided your GY is free of Traps. Believe me when I say that Time Thief Redoer LOVES being summoned with this card under it, since then it gets its floating and bounceback effects online right out the gate. You'll want to run one because, well, later in the game you'll definitely have a Trap or two in the GY for one reason or another, so it's best to use those extra slots for cards like the next entry.
  • That next one being Phantom Knights' Fog Blade. It's pretty much a tribal Fiendish Chain, targeting a monster of choice to prevent it from having its effects, attacking, or being attacked. But its utility doesn't stop there, since it banishes itself from the GY to revive a Phantom Knight of your choosing. That latter one was a boon that I'd overlooked for the longest time, but now I see the full scope of what this baby does for the deck.
  • As far as this next backrow slot, Phantom Knights' Sword and Phantom Knights' Wing are practically the same card, equipping to a monster to power it up and offer destruction defense and reviving a PK by banishing themselves from GY. I personally say run whichever of these two you prefer, or both. I just choose to run Sword 'cause, well, I dunno. Guess I'm a big sword doofus or something.
  • Another card that PK's are thankful to have unbanned (albeit a couple months or so back) would be The Phantom Knights' Rank-Up-Magic Launch. Sure, Rank-Up-Magic Phantom Knights' Force is also a thing, but it's moreso for a build of PK and Raidraptor and stuff like that or if you really, REALLY wanna go for Arc Rebellion that badly. But in this case, we'll be running Launch so we can go into a certain stained-glass bungus, or if we're feeling crazy and wanna promote Break Sword into Redoer or Perpetua if we need. It also banishes from GY to attach a PK from hand to an Xyz of your choice, but obviously the promotion takes center stage here.

Xyz Dragon

Not quite Phantom Knights, not quite Raidraptors, but still very much considered to be key parts of DARK Xyz stuff. Hoo wow, take a shot every time I say "DARK Xyz" in this article and your liver will implode. Anyways, when you need a good beatstick or some strong bungus control options, these guys have your back.
  • And it all starts with Dark Rebellion Xyz Dragon. Pretty much the definition of a beatstick, he detaches both his materials to slurp up half the ATK of an opponent's monster and gives it to himself. Pretty standard stuff, but that's only to enable his Rank-Up into...
  • ...a guy who's surprisingly lacking a golden heart-shaped arrow, Dark Requiem Xyz Dragon. Aside from looking like he belongs on a goth album cover, provided that he has Dark Rebellion under him as material, he can either slurp up ALL of an opposing monster's ATK for himself, or more often, detach a material as a Quick Effect to negate a monster effect, destroy the one who attempted to use it, and optionally revive an Xyz from the GY. Not only does he only add to PK's recursiveness, but he's the real big reason we tend to run RUM Launch.
  • And now for Phantom Rage's very own cover card, though let's hope he doesn't cost too much once he pops up stateside. Arc Rebellion Xyz Dragon provides the best of both worlds from his brothers, and is made all the more easy to go into by Raiders' Knight, which you'll more often than not be using as the sole method or bringing him out. Detaching a material only locks you into attacking with him for the turn, but has it gain the ATK of all other monsters on the field while also negating all their effects (including your own) while it has a DARK Xyz attached to it. And that latter part remains, so really only bring this guy out as a coup de grace to smack your opponent for well, well over lethal.

Danger!

Hoo boy, remember these guys? The set of creepy-crawly cryptids that certain decks tend to run as a draw engine and way to get bodies for extra summons on the board? Thankfully, you'll be spared from the mass Thunderbird! and Bigfoot! plops in hopes of making Hope Harbinger, as the Danger! monsters here are pretty much for, well, making other Xyz, albeit at lower ranks and maybe also to use as material for Bardiche. Pretty much every Danger! monster has the primary effect of randomly discarding a card and bringing itself out if it was unhit to draw one, so I'll spare the repetition there and go for the secondary effects in listing each of these out.
  • First of which is Danger! Mothman!. It'll be one of your main means of aiming for a Rank 4, though its discard lets you draw one and then discard one, so if summoning it didn't work out, you can pitch another card of choice from your hand for their own effect.
  • Speaking of pitching Danger!s, that's where Danger! Chupacabra! comes in. When he hits the GY upon discarding, he revives a Danger! of choice other than himself, though you'll likely be going into Mothman! for more Rank 4's or in the case of the next pick, for Rank 3's.
  • Danger!? Tsuchinoko? pretty much summons itself regardless of whether or not it's hit with its own effect, since its secondary one brings itself out if discarded. A pretty good pal for all the Main Deck PK's in this regard, since they can make Break Sword and the like.
  • The other Level 3 happens to be Danger!? Jackalope?, which four out of five times you'll want to discard, along with the last Danger! on this list. Main reason being that it summons a Danger! directly from deck, making it all the easier to go into either Mothman! or Tsuchinoko? if you're lacking L3's or 4's to build stuff out of.
  • And last but not least, the searcher comes in the form of Danger! Nessie!. This final must-discard searches any Danger! monster of choice, so more often than not you'll want to empty your hand of all but this, activate its effect to search for Jackalope?, then use that guy to bring out a L4 or 3 right away. Pretty easy stuff, right?

Other Main Deck Staples

The next four cards really don't belong to a set archetype, but have totally earned their places here one way or another.
  • After all, what would a DARK-based deck be without Armageddon Knight? Searchable with RotA and a simple summon Foolish Burial's a DARK monster of choice. That, and he's a L4, so you can go into Redoer or any of your staple R4's with ease.
  • Speaking of, Reinforcement of the Army! Just as any DARK deck has a mandatory Armageddon, any Warrior deck lacks completion if it lacks this card. And this Spell gives you the choice of Armageddon himself or any of your PK's.
  • Foolish Burial is, well, what Armageddon, Tear Scale, and Rusty Bardiche tend to be minus the tribalism or xenophobia. Any monster in your deck can step right up to be sent to the GY this way, including the next spot here.
  • A bird in a set of knights, armor and machines? Outsiders to how DARK Xyz decks run may scratch their heads at the sight of Blackwing - Zephyros the Elite here, but he's got a pretty decent niche. At the cost of 400 LP, he bounces a face-up card of yours back to your hand to revive himself for a very, very odd "once-per-Duel" thingie. Something crazy I've been able to do a couple times is bring out a Danger! with its own effect, bounce it back to my hand with Zephyros, and use the Danger!'s effect in hand AGAIN for another free summon and draw. You likely won't get to do that often, but it feels oddly satisfying when it does.
  • Other than that, though, feel free to swap out any Main Deck card you'd prefer as something else for anything in the Side Deck. Monster Reborn for generic revival, Time Thief Startup to get another Time Thief out of your hand for free, all that good stuff.

Extra Deck Staples

Let's not forget about all the other Extra Deck stuff, though! Time Thieves and PK's fill their roles well here, but what about all the others?
  • Like, say, Tornado Dragon! It's a walking Mystical Space Typhoon once a turn, popping a backrow by detaching a material. Your Time Thief cards can make this thing easily, as can your Danger!s. But there's another generic Rank 4 that can do that job as well.
  • Abyss Dweller may not see too much play nowadays, but can be pretty situational by shutting off your opponent's ability to use GY cards for the whole turn, during ANY phase of ANY turn. You won't bring it out too often, but when it does its job, it can really pay off.
  • Upset that your banished PK's can't be of use anymore? Well, that's no longer the case with the little ditty known as Leviair the Sea Dragon! A generic Rank 3, detaching a card from him lets you bring back any banished Level 3 or 4 monster of your choice. PK gone? No problem! Bezel Ship, Regulator, or Chronocorder down for the count in the same way? That too's a thing of the past! See what I mean by incredible recursion?
  • Speaking of generic Rank 3's, Dante, Traveler of the Burning Abyss makes his appearance, though it's not likely you'll be bringing him to the field outside of general milling or just to get some extra ATK to go for lethal or something.
  • With all these Level 3's running around, what would this deck be without Cherubini, Ebon Angel of the Burning Abyss? It is just about the only other one of its kind here, aside from Dante, and he's got a much more useful effect. Any monster he points to can't be axed off by card effects, and he can protect himself by letting you send another card you control to the GY instead. Not only that, but he also acts as a Foolish Burial for any Level 3 of your choosing to power himself up (though the first half of that is what you're aiming for) and a way to get two Level 3's into the GY from field so their effects can take place. Boy, am I thankful this guy got reprinted in the 2020 Tin of Lost Memories. Among all the Extra Deck tech reprints and the questionable addition of yet more support for DM's two vanilla lovechildren, I'll try and look out for this guy solely. Well, him and the next card.
  • A machine, in a group of master criminals and ghostly warriors? Yeah, a big boss in many Xyz decks and something that can be situational yet very worthwhile here is Infinitrack Fortress Megaclops. Requiring 3 Xyz monsters of any kind, any attempt for your opponent to walk over this guy or bash it with monster effects from anything besides an Xyz monster is futile. Not only that, but his activated effect revives an Xyz of choice from your GY, then attaches any card your opponent has to it as material. Imagine the shock on their face when you revive Redoer with this guy, attach your opponent's Trap to it, and then use Redoer to
  • Don't let all these Extra Deck placements stop you from using other cards, however. Bujinki Ahashima, for example, is pretty much a lite version of Rusty Bardiche that can revive two cards of the same level to immediately use for an Xyz, and Number 41: Bagooska the Terribly Tired Tapir can be your emergency button if you're lacking in options against your opponent's main tools, and any Link monster of yours is safe from it and free to pop off to pick off those threats.
  So that's the deck as a whole. But before I close, just wanna give you some good tips to help play to the best of your ability.

Handy Notes for Play

  • With Regulator, you'll want to go into Winder and Chronocorder typically, though if Winder's in your hand change it to Chronocorder and Bezel Ship. When you summon Redoer using these two, use Winder to detach a material to summon itself, then Redoer's effect to detach the remaining monster on it and bounce out. That way, Chronocorder will revive itself and you can then use it and Winder to go into another Rank 4, like Perpetua or Tornado Dragon. If you can get another Level 4 body on the field, you can then revive Bezel Ship from the GY by detaching a material from that other Rank 4, then use it and the other L4 for another Rank 4. So it's definitely possible to get three Rank 4's up turn one, and then use Perpetua during your opponent's turn to revive Bezel Ship from GY so it can use its Quick Effect snatch.
  • Redoer can be a Swiss army knife, with the way he lets you draw, bounce back, and avoid disruptive effects. Just know where and when to proc them, like if Redoer himself is being targeted for a disruption or if your opponent's about to bring a big mean boss to the field that'll spell danger for you if you don't detach a Trap right there. That being said, if you're going to proc his effect to bounce himself out and dodge stuff, make sure to also detach Spells and Traps on him at the same time to get the most out of his momentary exit. Just watch out for Ash's, Ghost Ogres, or things of the sort that can stop him dead in his tracks.
  • It's not the end of the world if Phantom Knight cards end up in the GY before you want them to. That's where stuff like Tear Scale and Rusty Bardiche come in. These two could send Fog Blade or Sword/Wing that way to then banish themselves to revive the PK's you desire. Bonus points if Tear Scale is in the GY with them, since it revives itself in the process without necessarily needing either of those Traps to do so.
  • RUM Launch is primarily for Ranking-Up Dark Rebellion into Dark Requiem, but don't forget that you can use Break Sword on the field to make Redoer or Perpetua in a pinch when you need, including reviving Break Sword during your opponent's turn with Fog Blade or Sword/Wing.
  • Perpetua puts in quite a bit of work as well. Don't take for granted the fact that she can attach any Time Thief card from deck to any Xyz monster you control to reload their resources. Putting another Flyback or Retrograde on Redoer's just as important, but don't forget to keep Dark Requiem and Tornado Dragon going strong in the same way, too!
  • Again, only use Arc Rebellion as a game-ender, because after you get off his effect, there's not really any going back seeing as how everything on the field, including your own stuff, has essentially been Skill Drain-ed and your opponent may or may not have a nasty backrow card pop up during battle that would put every hole in your plan possible. Sure, it's a great closer, but not without its risks. And you don't have to rely solely on it as a wincon, either.
All in all, Time Thieves and Phantom Knights are a fun deck with cool nonlinear combo lines and methods of snagging a win, in my personal opinion. It might not shatter things like Adamancipator, Dogmatika, or any of the umpteen Eldlich builds as quick as a snap anytime soon, but I like to think that it can hold its own and shatter expectations in the right hands and mindset. If I were to cap the strategy as a whole off, I'll say that experience is the best teacher when it comes to this deck, so feel free to give it a whirl for yourself and see just how many heads you can make spin with these DARK doofuses. Either that, or splash Dogmatika in place of certain things if you're feeling crazy or just one of those people. Regardless, I hope you have fun the way I did learning and optimizing this deck over the past several months or so. Thanks for giving my decklist a read, as well as my other ones! I honestly wasn't expecting my last Time Thief/Phantom Knight build to reach the amount of clicks it got or wind up as the top Google result for "time thief phantom knight" if I'm reading it right. Don't mean to toot my own horn, but I'm glad I got as far with these guys as I did. Maybe they'll reach meta relevancy, maybe not. But either way, you won't see me quitting on them anytime soon.

deck_excerpt: This is a better version of my Meklord Orcust deck with a better breakdown.
deck_description: This deck goes second. Meklord Astro Dragon Triskelia hits harder than most Train monsters. Imagine a 8k atk monster (at best) with 3 attacks; Liebe would be shaking. The Meklord part of this deck hits hard while the Orcust part is good at controlling the game and protecting your Meklords. Usually, I would talk about the side deck near the end of a breakdown like this, but I'm gonna discuss it now. Side in card according to the environment of your locals or the popular decks your opponents play online. If there are more combo decks, Forbidden Droplet and Infinite Impermanence are the better choice instead of Cosmic Cyclone or Lightning Storm. If there are more control decks, Lightning Storm and Cosmic would be better. Effect Veiler is at one in the main deck for the option to go into Selene Accesscode Talker combo. Fallen of Albaz is a target for Nadir Servant which sends Infernoble Knight Captain Roland. Roland equips himself to a warrior. Triskelia turns into a warrior when made one with Reprodocus. Now, Triskelia has the opportunity to become at least an 8000 ATK monster with 3 attacks. Triskelia gains ATK equal to the combined ATK of the monsters equipped to it. Look, this deck can fall to Ash Blossom. It's a complete glass cannon. Since Called By the Grave is limited since the last banlist (to SELL Triple Tactics Talent), it's more of a brick in this deck than a form of protection. Full combo is Meklord Astro Dragon Triskelia, Meklord Army Arsenal of Obbligato, and Girsu, the Orcust Mekk-Knight. Obbligato is a one card Platinum Gadget which gets you to Girsu and sets up Triskelia also. Plat Gadget summons Girsu to do your Orcust combo and it gets your Galatea co-linked to prevent it from being run over to turn off Crescendo (if you went first). With the amount of Orcust extenders you have, your first turn board is decently protected and it provides a feasible amount of protection for you to OTK with Triskelia. Orcust engine consists of Girsu, the Orcust Mekk-Knight, Orcust Knightmare, Orcust Brass Bombard, Orcust Cymbal Skeleton, World Legacy - World Wand, Galatea, the Orcust Automaton, Longirsu, the Orcust Orchestrator, Dingirsu, the Orcust of the Evening Star, Orcustrated Return, and Orcust Crescendo. Crescendo is nice as you can banish it to search a dark machine like Girsu or Triskelia. Foolish Burial Goods can send Crescendo. The Meklord part consists of Meklord Astro Dragon Triskelia, Meklord Army Arsenal of Obbligato, Meklord Army of Wisel, Meklord Army of Skiel, and Meklord Assembly. We aren't playing Meklord Nucleus Infinity Core since this isn't a pure Meklord deck where you are also playing the Meklord Emperors. Spell and Trap lineup get you to your combo pieces quicker. One for One might be dead most of the time since you are only playing one Brass Bombard, so you could replace it with like World Legacy - Succession or Monster Reborn. Extra Deck consists of Salamangreat Almiraj and Linkuriboh for simple grave set-up. Reprodocus and Infernoble Knight Captain Roland for the Triskelia meme. Galatea, Longirsu, Dingirsu, and Platinum Gadget for the Orcust stuff. Gear Gigant for searching Girsu if you have another way to summon him. Titanikland the Ash Dragon and Elder Entity N'tss as targets for Nadir Servant and a target for Fallen of Albaz. Accesscode Talker and Selene, Queen of the Master Magicians since we are playing Effect Veiler. You can play Halqifibrax in this deck, but just take out Reprodocus, Roland, and the Nadir Servant and Fallen of Albaz along with N'tss and Titaniklad. We aren't playing Meklord Army of Granel since you know, we have better normal summons in this deck.

deck_excerpt: Updated with new generic Fire support
deck_description: This deck go second since it makes things that non-quick-effect interact with your opponent's board. Ash Blossom and Lightning Storm should be enough for you to get advantage out for turn 2. As per usual, your Main Deck Shiranuis are 3 Spiritmaster, 3 Squire, 3 Solitaire, 1 Samurai, and 2 of both Spectralsword and Spectralsword Shade. You are of course playing 3 Uni-Zombie and 3 Mezuki for that generic zombie support. You would rather have Solitaire or Uni-Zombie be your Normal Summon with Squire, Spiritmaster, and Samurai be in the grave for you to reborn and use as synchro material. Your Shiranuis also have their banished effects. Spiritmaster is removal, Solitaire and Samurai are for recycling, and Squire refreshes your hand and sets up your grave. Your Spectralswords do what they do. They use your graveyard as an opportunity to get more advantage through banishing and synchro summoning. They also allow you to get to the Plaguespreader synchros without having to use Plaguespreader specifically. Spells and Traps in the main deck are for basic set-up. Gold Sarc banishes your Shiranuis from deck so that you can get their effects off. Ghost Meets Girl - A Shiranui's Story gets you to Solitaire which gets you to Uni-Zombie and it sets up your grave. Mayakashi's Manuscript is a better Shiranui card than a Mayakashi card. It's basically a reborn for any Shiranui in your gy or that is banished. Foolish Burial Goods has 2 targets: Shiranui Style Success and Return of the Zombies. Style Success is a trap that gets a zombie on field, but it can banish itself from the grave to make a zombie a Towers for the turn. Return of the Zombies is only a Foolish Goods target for now as it can recycle banished zombies and it can get you to your Shiranui's banished effects. If you go first, you can use this along with Zombie World to be monster removal. Extra deck has your generic Shiranui Extra Deck cards and more possible synchro targets. Red-Eyes Zombie Necro Dragon is a beater and it takes your opponent's monsters. Sunsaga is of course your boss monster. Shogunsaga is to get out some damage, Samuraisaga is a recycler, and Squiresaga is probably the best low level Shiranui Synchro. It's good removal in general. Lavalval Salamander is a good choice going second since its grave set-up, a way to access your Shiranui's banished effects, and it has a Book of Moon effect. Psy-Framelord Omega since this deck does banish cards. Archfiend Zombie Skull to prevent board wipes. And Revived King Ha Des since hes a good beatstick (feel free to swap him out for like a different synchro). Yuki-Onna since it is an amazing card if you manage to make it. Skillsaga Supremacy for more protection. And Vampire Sucker since this is a Zombie Deck. The link monsters are very limited since there isn't much recursion that they alone provide compared to the synchro monsters in the deck. Side Deck has Nibiru since Shiranui doesn't break massive boards. Neo Flamvell Lady as a Uni-Zombie replacement if you use Burning Draw and it's also a pseudo D.D. Crow. Burning Draw to draw 3 or 4 cards usually. Zombie World since it is a great floodgate that this deck can manage to play. And Infinite Impermanence for more disruption.

deck_name: Eldlich Control, Sept 2020 Post Ban List
deck_excerpt: I still like Eldlich as a pure control deck best personally.
deck_description: Eldlich control for the new format.  The Eldlich suite is still the same, 3 of each trap monster to take advantage of the deck's grind game, 3 red and 2 white eldlixer, the red is an important one, but when you're focusing on the grind game you want a second copy to search, 3 of the searcher and Golden Lord, obviously key to the deck's strategy, and 1 of the counter trap, the deck's main omni-negate.  Lost Wind still makes the cut, but Magicians' Souls does not. In this meta, sending your Solemn and Red Lotus is really really bad, given Harpie's Feather Duster is in the meta. The deck runs Extravagance with virtually no cost anyways. The Red Lotus is a meta call, I'm expecting Harpie's to be in a lot of mains for the first little while, and it is a very good check on Eldlich. With Block Dragon gone, Called By The Grave is just a more generically useful way to banish Golden Lord, with a lot of varied applications. I honestly wouldn't run more than 1 anyways, but it's a good one of, to negate an Eldlich while banishing another, or even just stopping Ash. With Called at 1 and Numerons not represented at all, I think it is safe to shift back to Ash from Gamma, especially given this is a going first grind game deck that wants its hand traps to stay live late into the game. Imperm is also obligatory in any backrow deck, and in most main decks. 1 negate is good, the potential second negate is useful, and it is a hand trap that distracts from your other back row.  In the Side Deck there are 3 Waking the Dragons, for game 2 and 3, when the hoard of backrow removal comes in to attack. I don't think you need it in the main deck, given that game 1 most people will only have Harpie's, if that. We also have Harpie's and Red Reboot. Red Reboot is game if you can get your trains going in the mirror, and Harpie's is obligatory. I've also got 3 Cosmic Cyclone, to banish Eldlich trap monsters, which as continuous traps actually negates - also good against Cursed Eldland. Ra is our normal summon. Since we don't have one, we might as well take advantage of Sphere mode to out combo boards. 3 Forbidden Droplet and 1 Dark Ruler No More are also for combo decks - even just getting set up under their monsters, maybe break their board a little, is huge advantage, and Droplet's effect to discard is often upside in the deck. Dark Ruler No More is basically just copy #4.  Added Dogmatika Punishment, with 3 N'tss, for the double pop, over maindeck Appointer of the Red Lotus, a card that is only good going first and only necessary games 2 and 3. I'd considered Compulse, and if you have the Extra Deck space and don't need the extra deck, Punishment is just better.

deck_name: Counter Every Popular Deck! Anti-Meta Stun
deck_excerpt: Do you miss simple and easy "caveman" Yugioh? Anti-Meta Stun is the perfect budget choice! Slow the game to a halt by stopping special summoning and b
deck_description: The philosophy behind Anti-Meta Stun is that most decks nowadays are woefully under-prepared if they cannot special summon, and usually do not have easily accessible outs to spell and traps, unless they draw into it. This deck's goal is to protect and enhance it's anti-special summon monster floodgates with backrow support. The equip cards are to boost our floodgate's lacking attack and to provide situational effects. (Moon Mirror Shield and Mage Power for beating over stronger monsters, Mordschlag to destroy special summoned monsters, Power of the Guardians to provide destruction protection and White Veil for backrow destruction. Armory Call essentially adds 3 more copies of each card in the deck.) 9  draw cards to facilitate consistency. This deck's price can be cut substantially by replacing Pot of Extravagance with something else and not including an extra deck. Prohibition is to disallow certain cards to be used crucial to a deck (For example, vs. Eldlich you prohibit Eldlich the Golden Lord). Prohibition can also be called to prevent the use of backrow removal (For example, prohibiting Twin Twisters, Cosmic Cyclone of Harpie's Feather Duster.) Counter traps are to prevent field wipes and destructive backrow cards from being activated such as Lightning Storm, Harpie's Feather Duster and Twin Twister. They are also useful for preventing negation cards like Infinite Impermanence from shutting off the our floodgate monsters for a turn. This deck excels at going first, as most meta decks cannot play through a hard to destroy special summon floodgate. Most of the time, they are forced to set and pass. This deck is particularly weak against destruction effects from spell/traps, and may likely suffer versus oppressive boards going second. The 10 traps in the deck can be replaced by handtraps to make it easier to go second.

deck_excerpt: New Infernoble combo, End board no extenders is VFD, Charles and 4 draws or Roland. Still can make Roland with extenders.
deck_description:
I'm not good at talking, but yeah, so... Basic combo is Make Charles and VFD with +4 in hand advantage. This doesn't use any extra extenders (your Infernobles) and can used for better endboards or making Isolde. The combo
  1. Make Isolde (Dont care how, just make him)
  2. Add level 3 FIRE warrior (This isn't important, just helps Astolfo being a level 3)
  3. Isolde's 2nd effect, summon genba, send smoke grenade and either durenal or living fossil.
  4. Linkross for 2.
  5. Halq, summon 001.
  6. Make Marcher, summon back genba.
  7. Make Auroradon, tribute itself and a token to summon out aerosguin.
  8. Summon Librarian in extra monster zone (it doesn't have to be the extra monster zone).
  9. Aerosguin effect, banish Auroradon and summon a token.
  10. Make Karakuri level 7, summon level 2.
  11. Make Karakuri level 9, summon level 4.
  12. Repeat steps 10 and 11
  13. Make VFD.
  14. Use whatever you drew to extend your plays.
  15. If your drew no extenders, use tuner and Librarian to go into Charles.
  16. Rip one during the end phase, and at the direct start of your opponents turn use VFD to block the type they are playing.
  17. Have fun.

deck_excerpt: Pure Zombie deck that prioritises lockdown and control.
deck_description:
ZOMBIE DECK COMBOS!!!

Combo 1: 2 Card Buster Lock + Baladroch

  1. You need Uni-Zombie and either Mezuki or Necroworld Banshee in hand.
  2. Normal summon Uni and discard one of the above cards and send the other from the deck to the graveyard.
  3. Revive Banshee with Mezuki effect.
  4. Summon Halqifibrax and chain the effect of Banshee to Halqifibrax's effect to get Zombie World on the field.
  5. Summon Glow-Up Bloom with Halqifibrax.
  6. Link summon Union Carrier with Halqifibrax and Glow-Up Bloom.
  7. Banish Glow-Up Bloom to summon Doomking Baladroch.
  8. Equip Dragon Buster Destruction Sword to Baladroch with Carrier.
  9. You have a 3800 atk baladroch and a buster lock.
(If you open Shiranui Solitaire and Mezuki/Banshee the combo works too)

Combo 2: Rivalry Lockdown

This isn't an extensive combo, but rather a combination of cards that can result in a powerful lockdown.
  1. You need to have Rivalry of Warlords in hand along with either Zombie World or at the very least access to Zombe World like Necroworld Banshee.
  2. With both Zombie World and Rivalry of Warlords on the field, unless your opponent is playing a Zombie deck or Zombie monsters consistently, they will be locked out of more than 1 monster.
  3. Rulings state that while Rivalry is out you cannot summon a mnster with a different type to what is on the field, and since Zombie World changes the type of all monsters on the field it means your opponent cannot summon anything except zombies.
  4. This also locks them out of the extra deck since the monster on field is a different type to whats in their extra deck, meaning they can't summon.

deck_excerpt: Swarm the field and then Link, XYZ Summon, and Synchro Summon into whatever the situation calls for!
deck_description: @Ignisters! Everyone thinks they can't do anything, and it's true that often they rely on the field spell. However, there are multiple strategies and ways to play through various negates as well as just create different boss monsters depending on the situation!  First of all, the monster 3-ofs. You've got a lot here, Pikari is your spell searcher (usually A.I. Land but also A.I.dle Reborn for graveyard recursion and TA.I. Strike for battle phase shenanigans), Balancer Lord allows synergy with Cyberse Wicckid, Parallel eXceed furthers your Link plays, and Achichi serves as a monster searcher. Along with these, Bururu at 2 is needed for Synchro plays but you don't want to see it in your hand (it's not a Garnet by any means, but is more useful in Wicckid combos from the deck). Doyon is run at 2 in order to recycle your @Ignister monsters and spells (very versatile), while Gatchiri is an extender that protects your Link monsters if used as material or just your Cyberse monsters when on the field. Doshin and Hiyari are also one-of extenders that special summon themselves for free, but they can be cut if need be.  Moving on to spells, I run 3 Cynet Mining (needed for any Cyberse deck) as well as 3 A.I. Land with 1 Terraforming (as I said above, really helps your plays). I also run 2 A.I.dle Reborn and 1 Monster Reborn for GY recursion (you could run 3 A.I.dle Reborn, but I feel safer at 2). I also run 2 TA.I. Strike for Battle Phase shenanigans (always fun to kill a Link God Dragon with a Pikari), and 2 Pot of Desires for draw power (you don't have much).  This leaves room for hand traps and other fun spells, I personally run 2 Cosmic Cyclone, 1 Called by the Grave, and 3 Ash Blossom in my main deck, but these can be exchanged with anything that's relevant for the current format.  Your Extra Deck is extremely tight, not because you're limited to a few options, but because you have so many plays that you can pull off. Starting with relatively common combo starters, I run 1 Cyberse Wicckid and 1 Splash Mage. Cyberse Wicckid is very useful with Balancer Lord to add from the deck and then special summon a Bururu from the hand, while Splash Mage is good to go into if you don't have that Balancer Lord in the GY. I also run 2 Linguriboh, because you need easy special summons from the Extra Deck as well as an easy way to free up the main monster zones if needed. 2 Dark Templars are necessary for this deck, being the main combo extender, but after this you can get extremely creative (as long as you use Cyberse Extra Deck monsters).  If you need to safely break a board and OTK, the 1 Accesscode Talker is a very good option. If you need to destroy opponent's monsters while providing protection for your own, summon one of the 2 Light Dragon @Ignisters. If you need to destroy opponent's spells and traps, summon the 1 Wind Pegasus @Ignister. If you wipe the board with Wind Pegasus and Light Dragon, go into the 1 Firewall Dragon Darkfluid with 2 counters to not only negate monster effects if need be but also just OTK. If you just need a Towers, summon the 1 Arrival Cyberse @Ignister. If you need to protect your Links (usually Accesscode), Synchro into Cyberse Quantum Dragon. And finally, if it's turn one or you really need to out an opponent's monster, go into the 1 I:P Masquerena and then the 1 Mekk-Knight Crusadia Avramax.  The side deck is pretty simple, just fill with whatever hand-traps you have at the time to fight the Meta (my current list is just what I own currently). However, leave 2 spots for Earth Golem @Ignister and A.I. Love Fusion. If your opponent is using a Link-heavy deck like Salamangreats or Sky Striker, simply side this in and watch your opponent's fast as you fusion summon using their own Link monsters. Think Super Polymerization but without the discard.     And that's @Ignisters! I'll explain the main combo piece that you want to get out with your deck. Normal Summon Balancer Lord, use his effect, and then Normal Summon Pikari. From here, go into Cyberse Wicckid and Special Summon any Ignister or Parallel eXceed from hand, banish Balancer Lord using Wicckid, and then Special Summon the Bururu you add off of Lord. Link into Dark Templar using 3 different named monsters, then special summon any monster to a zone it points to (either turn an eXceed into Linguriboh or special summon another Ignister from hand). From here, you can do pretty much anything you want to go into! This combo runs very similarly if you go into Splash Mage, it really just depends on what cards you're working with. I hope y'all learned something about this new Cyberse powerhouse, good luck Duelists!

deck_excerpt: The main idea behind this strategy is to eliminate key cards in your opponent's Deck and controlling their field.
deck_description: The archetype is supported by the Field Spell Card "Vampire Kingdom". The card is designed to augment the effects of "Vampire Lord", "Vampire Lady", "Vampire Duke" and "Vampire Grace". The Trap Card, "Vampire Takeover", is very handy for getting "Kingdom" onto the field, and as well as a free Special Summon from your Graveyard. "Vampires" make an effective Xyz Monster Deck. Using the effects of "Shadow Vampire" and "Vampire Duke" to Special Summon Level 5 DARK "Vampires" (such as each other or "Vampire Lord") and Overlay for the boss of the Deck: "Crimson Knight Vampire Bram". You can also use "Vampire's Curse" and "Vampire Grace" for Rank 6 plays (such as the unorthodox, yet still thematically fitting Number 24: Dragulas the Vampiric Dragon). "Vampires" obtained new support revolving around paying Life Points as costs to Special Summon themselves from the Graveyard and search other "Vampire" cards and taking control of the opponent's monsters, often by Special Summoning opposing Monsters that were destroyed by battle with a "Vampire". This also facilitates the Xyz Summon of "Damphir Vampire Sheridan" as it can treat monsters the player controls that are owned by the opponent as Level 6 when used for its Xyz summoning. The Life Point costs can then be recovered with the use of "Vampire's Domain". "Vampire Domain" allows an additional Normal Summon of a "Vampire" monster, this works in tandem with the Link Monster "Vampire Sucker", which allows the player to tribute the opponent's Zombie type monsters for the Tribute Summon of a "Vampire", it can also special summon a monster from the opponent's Graveyard to their field as a Zombie type so it can be used as tribute.

deck_excerpt: Yes, you heard me right...Genex. You can thank Halqifibrax for making all this possible.
deck_description:
1 Card Halqifibrax Combo!!!

  1. You need to have Genex Undyne in your hand.
  2. Normal summon Undyne and send Crystron Rosenix to the grave and add the Genex Controller to the hand.
  3. Banish Rosenix and summon a Crystron token, use the token to link summon Link Spider
  4. Special summon Controller with Link Spider
  5. Link away Controller and Link Spider into Halqifibrax
  6. Proceed to do the Arouradon combo into Coltwing and proceed to go wherever you please.
This deck lacks a real concrete win condition, its based entirely on winging it and making whatever synchro monster you can to edge closer to a victory. If you dont mind clunky gameplay and just wanna play a funky synchro spam deck, Genex can be fun.

I based this deck off of this Reddit post (go check it out and upvote it, it's very impressive) and the deck is very consistent with a lot of strategy; it's also not too expensive. For the tutorial on how to use the combo, look at the Reddit post. The deck can still perform relatively well without the combo, if something gets messed up.

deck_excerpt: I lied. Eldlich Dogmatika is my favourite Eldlich Varient. I'd just built it poorly before.
deck_description: I decided to give the Dogmatika engine a second go in Eldlich. The first time I hadn't incorporated Dogmatika Punishment, (or Titaniklad) but after thinking about the card a bit I think it is so generic to run, and gets you so much value on its own, that I was thinking of incorporating it into pure Eldlich, but if I was trying the card I wanted to try it with the searchers first.  The Eldlich package is very much my standard set. Sometimes you wish those white eldlixers were black, but generally, I prefer to see white, and you need 2 non reds to search. 2 Solemn Judgement seems essential, especially right after the ban list, with 1 Harpie's Feather Duster a lot of people will have main deck back row sweeping potential, which can result in getting OTK'd if you have no response. Judgement is still the best generic response, and a couple main for that lone Harpie's seems good.  Nadir Servant is the nuts, there's a lot of value here. On the face, you can send Titaniklad to search Ecclesia, which in turn searches you Punishment and Fleurdelis. That's 2 interruptions on 1 card, without a lot of commitment to the main or extra deck. However, it can also send ANY card from the extra deck. We've got 1 main Shaddoll Schism, and 1 Apkallone, meaning Nadir Servant can discard a card to search an extra card. Having the option to discard Golden Lord while getting him Fodder is pretty huge, and so is the ability to discard Golden Land trap monsters to search red Eldlixers. This also gives us access to the Winda combo game 2, but the real purpose game 1 is just to recur the trap a few times and use it to summon Golden Lord, as well as giving the deck a way to discard off of Nadir Servant. Ecclesia is an important tool for getting Nadir Servant's full value - you aren't taking full advantage of its capabilities by using it as a normal summon, but it's good enough of a normal summon to be a 3 of. Fleurdelis sucks, but you need to run 2. Needing a Dogmatika monster on the field is annoying most times you see him naturally, but you need a couple copies - this is a control deck, and being able to search a second copy in the game is really essential. The card is better once you know it is safe to side in Maximus - even with just 1 Maxmius in the deck it feels less like a brick, so this card gets better with Maximus. 2 Punishment seems obligatory, and I might want to try 3 of these with 3 N'tss in random control decks (if they have the space), including "pure" Eldlich. 2 pops for 1 is really good, and having other good targets to send makes the card much better. Hand traps should be standard - I don't like Gamma in control decks very much, so it's Ash, Effect Veiler and Impermanence.  The extra deck has a few packages. One is the Dogmatika Send package: 2 Dragon Bastards, 2 Elder Entity N'tss, 1 Skull Knight, plus 1 each of Shaddolls Apkallone, Winda, and Construct. The deck can turbo out Winda game 2 when this is a viable strategy, and can make Construct while popping a Light monster game 1 pretty easily, but mostly these cards are here to send with Dogmatika cards for fun and profit.  The next package is the trains. Choo choo! OTK! I love that Eldlich cards are level 10, because I like trains.  After that is a small link package. Vampire Sucker is good card advantage once you've simplified the game state, and can be made with Eldlich cards. The Knightmares give you some extra removal out of the extra deck. You are locking yourself out of the extra deck a fair amount of the time, but you might as well run a few links for those turns where you can link summon.  In the Side Deck there are 3 Appointer of the Red Lotus and 1 Solemn Judgement. Appointer is very good going first, and can really help in game 2 when the Lightning Storms come in, which is also what Solemn is here for. If you know you're going first game 2 or 3, you should make space for these cards.  2 Maximus is fine, you have 9 searchers and not a lot of space. The card is really pushed, so if you're against a deck that seems really like a heavy combo deck with no space for meta calls to hurt Maximus you can gain insane advantage while disrupting plays a little. Also helps make Winda in matchups where Winda is really good.  3 Forbidden Droplet is great against Combo, especially post-ban. Sure, Infernoble, and like the Water deck, will basically make this card useless, but it is a Dark Ruler No More that can be fired off chained to a lingering effect to negate it, and our deck wants cards in the GY anyways. The rest is Backrow removal for other control matchups.

deck_excerpt: Strong anti-meta mid-range combo control. rivalry+zombie world is almost always an auto-win and can be sided out depending on the matchup.
deck_description: Floodgates in the form of rivalry, zombie world, and buster lock have never been stronger. Going first the deck can end on zombie world + Balerdroch with buster lock from a 2 card combo (uni-zombie/ solitaire and any extender.) We play 3 of both necroworld banshee and mezuki because they are our main extender in tandem with uni. Mothman can also be an extender when needed and can help un-clog brick hands. If you have two extenders in addition to solitaire/uni-zombie you can end on I:P+union carrier+ buster locked balerdroch and zombie world. Linkross and formula synchron/ metal marcher provide free advantage from summoning glow up bloom off of needlefiber, make kross with needle then synchro bloom with a token into formula. Draw 1 then make marcher with the last token and formula and bring back bloom. make union carrier with marcher and linkross if you dont have another extender and then link bloom into linkuriboh triggering bloom's eff, summoning out balerdroch then you can use union to equip baler.

deck_excerpt: What does it mean to be "Meta"?
deck_description: Okay so this deck is all about getting the broken Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon out asap, but if you can't get Dark Dragoon out just beat them down with the main deck. This deck is pretty basic and straight forward. Use Red-Eyes Fusion to summon Dark Dragoon using Dark Magician and Red-Eyes Black Dragon to utilize Dark Dragoon's effect to its fullest. Red-Eyes Insight is great to search out Red-Eyes Fusion. Red-Eyes Wyvern is great card to send to the graveyard for the coast. Using Dragon Shrine you want to send one of the Red-Eyes Black Dragon to the grave then sending The Black Stone of Legend to graveyard. Then use The Black Stone's effect to shuffle Red-Eyes Black Dragon back into the deck and add The Black Stone into you hand. Keep in mind the you can only use one of The Black Stone of Legend's effect per a turn so you'll have to wait for your next turn to use it's other effect. The Black Stone of Legend has a few good targets for it's first effect. Red-Eyes Archfiend of Lightning, Meteor Dragon Red-Eyes Impact, Red-Eyes Black Dragon, Red-Eyes Black Flare Dragon or Red-Eyes Alternative Black Dragon. Gemini Monster Effects- Upon their re-summoning Red-Eyes Archfiend of Lighting is basically crowd control destroying your opponents monster who have less DEF than 2500. Meteor Dragon Red-Eyes Impact becomes protection for your Red-Eyes monsters Red-Eyes Black Flare Dragon inflicts 2400 damage to your opponent at the end of the battle phase as long as damage calculations is done involving Red-Eyes Black Flare Dragon. Use the Virus cards when you are about to lose any card that can't be saved but can be the activation coast for them. Eradicator Epidemic Virus will take care of spells and traps that you opponent has in their hand, field or draw for 3 turns. Deck Devastation Virus will take care of low ATK power monsters on the field, hand, and drawn for 3 turns. Full Force Virus will take care of low DEF monsters on the field, hand, and drawn for 3 turns. Extra Deck Monsters Mecha Phantom Beast Dracossack is great to remove pesky cards using his effect by removing tokens that are summoned by removing Xyz materials from the card. Also having immunity while you control a token. Beast-Eyes Pendulum Dragon is mostly there for a 3000 beat stick that is easy to summon due to the contact fusion ability 1 DARK Dragon-type monster and a Beast-Type Monster thus the reason Kinka-byo in the deck. Starving Venom Fusion Dragon is just perfect for a deck that has DARK monsters to spare.

deck_excerpt: Blow up the field with Black Rose Dragon, and use Thunder Dragon Titan to control the board and swing for game!
deck_description: This deck should always run you less than $120 including side deck, card sleeves, field center and deck box. The goal is to use the Thunder Dragon cards to break boards, gain advantage, play through handtraps, and summon out a Thunder Dragon Titan. The Predaplants are to search out fusion spells and get a plant on board for Crossrose Dragon. Titan gains advantage when protecting itself from Black Rose Dragon on the opponent's turn, and hopefully get a large amount of advantage from the board wipe. The artifact engine is to use any extra bodies to search Artifact Scythe, who can be popped by either Titan or Black Rose to lock the opponent out of the extra deck.

deck_excerpt: Extra Deck Monarchs never looked this good. This deck isn't for the faint of heart Monarchs have always lacked consistency but Pantheism at 3 gives bo
deck_description: I have always been a nostalgic person and I have always played monarch decks since I returned to Yu-gi-oh one year ago. I loved monarchs because it revolved around one of the oldest yugioh mechanics always excited me. I have only recently started back playing Yu-gi-oh but I have never been a fan of the tier-0 meta decks and I would only suggest this deck for those who like to win in style. There are several variants of this deck profile, but this version gives the greatest consistency with more than enough firepower to decimate your opponents. in an environment where you are likely to be blown up in an FTK or confront an unbreakable board in your first turn the ability to disrupt your opponents flow is critical that is what this deck focuses on. Be warned however- your success with this deck relies heavily on your knowledge of your opponents likely moves but picking the right time to intervene can completely disrupt their flow and give you an avenue to take complete control of the game from that point on. Your psyframes are your first line of attack disrupting their pesky cards- if you are lucky: you may have your field card in play to synchro summon into a boss monster - I personally prefer Omega and Draco however there are a quite a number of useful options the real beauty begins however if you have Ehther in your graveard or were able to set escalation- after tribute summoning Ehther and loading your graveyard with dynamite for your turn you can escalate into Erebus or my favorite Zaborg unleashing your extra deck unto the field. Elder Entity N'Tiss, zeta and omega are often my go to targets but the possibilities are endless. At the end you are left with a clear field to start the process all over again should they dare to play on their turn.  Monarchs are back... its time to take your throne.

deck_description: So, Konami put Tour Guide of the Underworld to 3, and Graff and Cir to 2 on the September 2020 TCG banlist. Since the two main characters of Devil May Cry are named "Dante" and "Virgil", I believe this is an appropriate name for a Burning Abyss deck.  And because I am a degenerate with no real concern for my opponent's enjoyment of the game, this deck uses 9 hand traps and Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon(Konami, PLEASE don't ban this card). My first turn-strategy would be to end on a board of Verte Anaconda, Dragoon, and Beatrice, which is a lot easier for Burning Abyss to do now that the deck is almost at full power.     Personally, in my duels with this deck, I've done better going first. Maybe you'll have different experiences than me and do better going second.

deck_excerpt: A Spellcaster Deck, featuring the Elemental Charmers, their Familiar Possessed versions, and the Familiars. Additionally, many different Spellcasters
deck_description:
(Card names are highlighted by their Bold Attribute Color. Archetypes are Bolded Black. Extra Deck monsters are indicated with ⌈Half-Brackets⌋) This deck obviously heavily revolves around the Charmers and Possessed monsters, and obviously there's a lot of cards here. First thing to note is that there aren't very many multi-copy cards. In fact, the only Main Deck cards with multiples are Angraecum Umbrella (x3), and the Charmer/Possessed Spells/Traps, although there is the option of swapping out attributes from the Side Deck based on your opponent's deck. Primary Strategy: So, the main objective of this deck is to try and get out ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ (2), which is objectively the Deck's strongest card, especially while Awakening of the Possessed is out, and also because it's the only Generic Fortune Lady monster, not requiring any other Fortune Lady cards to activate its effects. This takes a while at first and it will likely catch the opponent by surprise. The only Tuners in this deck are the Angraecum Umbrellas. However, the useful part is that they have the same stats (ATK/ 500, DEF/1500) as the Charmers, so they can be easily summoned from the Hand/Deck/Graveyard by the effects of Unpossessed, Teamwork of the Possessed, Familiar Possessed - Lyna, Eda the Sun Magician, and Awakening - Nefarious. Not only that, but its own effect can allow you to bring one of your Familiar Possessed (Lv 4) monsters from the GY, allowing you to easily summon Fortune Lady Every. Since most decks run Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring, another way of summoning ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ involves getting out ⌈Hiita the Fire Charmer, Ablaze⌋. Since Ash Blossom is a (Lv 3, FIRE) Tuner, whenever your opponent uses Ash Blossom, try to prioritize getting out ⌈Hiita, Ablaze⌋ as quickly as possible. Then you can just summon any of the Familiar Possessed monsters to bring out ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋. You can also use ⌈Selene, Queen of the Master Magicians⌋ to help bring back your Tuners, so you can summon the other Synchros, or even bring back ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ without having to banish. Actually, another sort of situational technique is using Spiritual Light Art - Miyabi, tributing ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ to summon a Banished monster, and since ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ comes back, it's no real loss. You can make summoning ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ even easier by using DNA Surgery. Then if you have Ranryu, Inari Fire, Jigabyte, or Nefarious Archfiend of Nefariousness (the Familiars) in your hand, while the Tuner is out, you can just Special Summon the Familiars, and since they'll automatically be Spellcasters, you can just as easily get out ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋. Alternate Strategy: Another Synchro Monster to pay attention to is ⌈Datascape Fox - Xianxian⌋. If you have 2 Charmers out along with Angraecum Umbrella, it's an easy Summon. It's not a Spellcaster, but it can be useful in conjunction with Nefarious Archfiend of Nefariousness to keep banishing your opponents' cards without having to banish yours. Just tribute ⌈Datascape Fox - Xianxian⌋ to Summon Nefarious from the GY. That way you can use Nefarious for another Synchro, Xyz, or Link summon. Then, before you end your turn, just bring ⌈Datascape Fox - Xianxian⌋ back from the GY with its effect. Then, even if you banish Nefarious, you can bring it back to the GY with ⌈Datascape Fox - Xianxian's⌋ other effect, making this, along with ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ both truly recyclable monsters. Other Useful Monsters:
  • Blizzard Princess Due to its effect, it's a fairly easy monster to summon, considering the whole deck is Spellcasters, and it's also the strongest card in the Main Deck, so it's a plus to have either way. You can use Endymion Lab to easily bring it out.
  • ⌈Alchemic Magician⌋ Slightly more difficult to bring out than ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋, since it requires 3 Level 4 Spellcasters. However, the benefit is it allows you to bring back up to 3 useful Spells, namely Awakening of the Possessed, Grand Spirit Art - Ichirin, and/or Masters of the Spiritual Arts, although Pot of Acquizitiveness is useful as well, since both of your strongest Synchros require Banishing monsters to use them effectively. Since it has ATK/1500 and DEF/1500, many of your Spell/Trap effects will work in conjunction with this monster.
  • ⌈Number 104: Masquerade⌋ Like Alchemic Magician, requiring 3 Lv 4 monsters, although they don't have to be Spellcasters. Useful for negating up to 3 Battle Phase effects, as well as milling your opponent's deck every turn.
  • ⌈Leviair the Sea Dragon⌋ Seemingly the most out of place monster here, but since your Synchros revolve around Banishing monsters, this card can come in handy. Also since half of your monsters are Lv 3, this card isvery easy to Summon.
  • Chocolate Magician Girl Especially useful if you already have Unpossessed out. You can use this monster to not only get an extra draw, but if the card you discard is a Charmer, then you can use Chocolate's effect next turn to bring that Charmer back and potentially even deal some chip damage due to the Charmers' decent DEF.
  • Magical Broker Very useful, especially since it has ATK/1500 DEF/ 200, so you can use Grand Spirit Art - Ichirin's effect to swap Dharc the Dark Charmer out to get it. Since your deck would have a lot of Continuous Spells/Traps, this card could be very hard for your opponent to get rid of. Then you could of course use it to get an extra draw if you happen to have multiple Awakening of the Possessed or Unpossessed cards out, or if you already have Teamwork or the Possessed in your GY, you can just use its effect to bring that card you just sent to the GY back to the field.
  • ⌈Explosive Magician⌋ & ⌈Arcanite Magcian⌋ (Synchro Magicians) Though not recyclable like ⌈Fortune Lady Every⌋ and ⌈Datascape Fox - Xianxian⌋ if either of the latter two get somehow Banished, or if they're already on the field, you can instead use the Synchro Magicians for sweeping. Since you can destroy opponents' Spells/Traps, or any cards in the case of ⌈Arcanite Magcian⌋.
Side Decking: The side deck consists mainly of extra copies of the Charmers as well as the other two Familiar Possessed cards. The important thing is to take note of the dominant Attributes of your opponent's deck, then swap accordingly. There are less Hiita the Fire Charmer cards, simply because FIRE monsters are the least common. You can also swap the Spirit Art Traps, since all have useful effects. Since your Deck would have predominantly WATER monsters, Spiritual Water Art - Aoi is likely your go to swap, especially if you find that your monsters aren't getting Banished enough to need Spiritual Light Art - Miyabi. I would always leave Familiar Possessed - Hiita, Familiar Possessed - Wynn, and Familiar Possessed - Aussa in the Main Deck. Since WATER is the dominant Attribute in this deck, it's much easier to Link Summon ⌈Eria the Water Charmer, Gentle⌋ than the other three Link Charmers. Otherwise, swap out the other Familiar Possessed monsters as you see fit. If necessary, you could also swap out Wynn the Wind Channeler/Medium with one of the Familiar Possessed monsters.

deck_excerpt: Infernoble combos and how to combo with bricks
deck_description: Pretty standard decklist, compared to some of my other deck profiles, but this profile is more meant to be a combo demonstration.  The "standard combo" post-banlist is probably been known to many, but in case you don't already know it, this is how it looks like:  Standard Combo:  https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=392223-21542285  This deck profile is meant to combo off if garnets are drawn. The answer is actually very simple - shuffle them back with Plaguespreader  Of course, that raises the ultimate question: what to do if Armageddon Knight or PSZ are drawn?  Combo if PSZ is drawn: (same board, except no draw 1 from Formula)  https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=392223-21542486  Combo if Armageddon Knight is drawn: (same board, you just need an warrior extender)  https://www.duelingbook.com/replay?id=392223-21543004  Hard-drawing DDR just means you can skip Power Tool

deck_excerpt: Draitron with Dragoon, what fun!
deck_description: Originally this was an Invoked Draitron deck, but then I realized that Dragoon is a better Mechaba, so I decided to go that way. Draitron can make Dragoon with frightening efficiency so long as they have access to Draitron Ban-Alpha, which they effectively have access to 13 copies of with all the searching they can do. from there, go off as hard as possible, setting up a graveyard full of Cyber Angel Benten (which you probably got off of Alpha) eventually summoning Cyber Angel Natasha, linking it away with something else for an Anaconda and viola! You have a graveyard full of snatch steals for link plays on your next turn, at least a Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon and maybe a Blue-Eyes Chaos MAX Dragon (or insert your favorite ritual monster here, I just like big heckin' chonkers).  In the extra deck, there are probably three extra spots. Apollusa doesn't get made a ton, you probably don't need a second Verte, Cerberus is...fine at best, and Black Luster Soldier is pretty much only ever getting made by stealing stuff with Natasha, which is fun, but maybe not super consistent. Have some fun with it.  It probably wouldn't be bad to try 3 Where Aft Thou to find more Draitrons, so that might be a change I make going forward, but it is a bit more situational than the others. If you only have one other draitron and don't have a ritual, it's just dead. Nothing else is dead like that (outside of the obvious garnets). Then again, this could just be me justifying a bad decision after the fact.  This whole post has two caveats.  First, you may have noticed something about this deck, and you're right. There is not a single normal summonable monster in this whole thing. You will lose to someone putting up a barrier statue when you're on the draw in game one. I don't think that's a big enough problem to sink this iteration of the deck, but I could be wrong.  Second, I don't know if this is ever going to be a deck that you can actually put together. Draitrons are set to come out in Genesis Impact, which is in December. Dragoon centralizes power in a way that probably isn't healthy for the game, and might not make it much past when the main part of the deck actually comes out. Heck, the OCG just banned it this week. If the TCG follows their example, we might not have this toy much longer. After that, invoked does good stuff, but it's not anywhere near as consistent or as powerful. It's a lot of fun on simulators for the moment.

deck_excerpt: Shooting Star Turbo. When you are about to summon him, it is mandatory to start playing Masaaki Endoh - Clear Mind at full blast.
deck_description: Shooting Star Turbo. Go first, summon Red Supernova Dragon. Go second, summon Shooting Star and pray you at least reveal 2 or 3 tuners. Our synchro tuner is Shooting Riser Dragon.  Junk Synchron, some way to summon Psi-Reflector, and some way to get a level 4 on the field is one Shooting Star Dragon. Junk Converter and a tuner is one Red Supernova Dragon.  Normal summon Junk Synchron or summon a tuner and activate Starlight Junktion. Emergency Teleport or One for One into Psi-Reflector. Add Assault Beast to hand with Psi-Reflector. Discard Assault Beast to add Assault Mode Activate from deck to hand. Reveal Assault Mode Activate with Psi-Reflector to special the Assault Beast back and increase it's level by 3. Synchro Assault Beast and Psi-Reflector to make Stardust Dragon. Then, you need a way to summon a level 4 monster. Monster Reborn or Synchro Chase to bring back the Assault Beast or Junk Servant Special summon itself from hand. Synchro that level 4 and Junk Synchron into Shooting Riser Dragon. Shooting Riser send Quickdraw Synchron to decrease its level by 5. Now, if you synchro the level 2 Shooting Riser Dragon with Stardust Dragon, you get a Shooting Star Dragon or a Satellite Warrior.  Discard Junk Converter and a tuner to add Junk Synchron to hand. Normal Junk Synchron and special back the Junk Converter. Synchro those into Junk Speeder and special back the Junk Synchron by Converter's effect and then Special, Junk Synchron, Cyberse Synchron, and Quickdraw Synchron from deck (mandatory to summon as many). Synchro with the 2 Junk Synchrons, the Cyberse Synchron, and Junk Speeder. (3+3+1+5=12) This gets a Red Supernova Dragon which banishes your opponent's field and itself. Then, it specials itself back after your next turn.  The other Synchros in the Extra Deck are for the moments where you have not other options. You can take out something like Junk Destroyer, Quasar/Blazar, and Stardust Charge Warrior to add in some link monsters I'm lazy to do so.  The side deck gets you to your combo easier.  Desires is somewhat good and bad in this deck. You get to combo pieces easier, but you are banishing names that are Junk Speeder targets, you are banishing parts of the Assault Mode stuff, and possibly banishing your Quickdraw Synchrons that are your Shooting Riser Dragon targets. I just didn't want to put in random "one of" cards that are very situational for this deck.

deck_excerpt: No Halq combo, no Linkross, no O-Lion/Jet shenanigan. Not the inconsistent "hoping-to-have-2-Crimson-Nova", we're using Duza for double Crystal Wing w
deck_description: Not your regular Aigami deck, Cubic is so inconsistent in OTK thanks to Crimson Nova ridiculous requirement and needs super specific setup to boost that buffoon to OTK. This deck is using Duza instead to establish board because it's a searchable Reborn Tengu, just add 1 random extender and we're good to go. So we need max copies of Duza, Summoner Monk, and Foolish Burial Goods (send Karma search Duza). To maximize the advantage, we need to use compatible extender like Summoner Monk (best, summons Duza from deck), Magicians Souls (super great, dumps your useless Cubic s/t on hand and draw), Apprentice Illusion Magician (same logic, but without draw), Danger Mothman (same logic, but the hand dump is random). Also we need to max Karma (for searching Duza) and Unification (combo piece). Combo is summon Duza + 1 extender, use Duza dump Unification, make Barricadeborg (can use its effect to dump Unification in hand, so combo is still running even if we draw it), use Unification 2nd Duza, use Duza dump 2nd Unification, make Auroradon, use Auroradon ss 3 tokens chain 2nd Unification summon 3rd Duza, use Duza dump 3rd Unification, use Auroradon tribute itself and 1 token ss Warbluran, make Phonon Pulse, make Bureido, use Bureido chain 3rd Unification, ss Shinkuro and Vijam, make Martial Metal Marcher, ss Shinkuro again, make Garden Rose, use Garden Rose add Black Garden (save it for Tzolkin requirement), make Crystal Wing, make Tzolkin using Crystal Wing (now tuner cus Marcher) + Bureido, use Garden Rose GY eff ss Crystal Wing from GY, set Black Garden use Tzolkin ss yet another Crystal Wing. You can use Black Garden to halve opponent's monster atk, but it makes Crystal Wing miss timing against on-summon effect because Black Garden activation is mandatory. The rest of the main deck is staple while extra deck is combo pieces and generic stuff, can use more Tzolkin target if you want. Pros: New approach for Cubic, consistent, big monster, with staple too. Cons: Only has monster negate, lack follow-up (can include Roland for Gearfried as follow-up by replacing Phonon Pulse, but needs brick like equip and Gearfried itself).
