deck_excerpt: Destiny Drawing in 2020
deck_description: A semi-pure Destiny Hero build built around fusion and link summoning. Your primary goal is to get 2 monsters on turn 1 and then link into Isolde grabbing Honest Neos, then binning Phoenix Blade to bring out Disk Commander and linking again into Anaconda for Fusion Destiny. You can also mix it up with Cross-Sheep, Mask Change, etc. D-Hero package: Plasma - Mainly a target for D-Draw, but his ability comes in handy and he's quite easy to summon in this deck. Malicious - Your staple D-Hero. Enables all your strongest plays. Celestial - Mainly fodder for D-Draw and Fusion Destiny, but you will be very thankful when you need either of his effects. Drilldark - A great enabler for link summons. Drawhand - A reasonable combo with Mask Change. You can chain Mask Change to his summon ability to swap into Dark Law and make your opponent banish a random card. You can also summon him off of Dominance getting merc'd at EOT from Fusion Destiny to get the card draw before your opponent. Lots of tricks with this fella, don't underestimate him. Disk Commander - A level 1 to retrieve with Isolde and a great target for Cross-Sheep and Dominance. Dark Angel - A backup level 1 for Isolde with a reasonable ability out of the grave. Pair him with Allure, D-Draw, or Drawhand to retrieve your card immediately. The rest: Honest Neos - Your best Isolde target since you don't need to play him to use him and he helps protect Dark Law. Stratos - We use his S/T clear effect almost as much as his recruit effect in here, surprisingly. Often our best Cross-Sheep target if Disco isn't available. Shadow Mist - Turns Foolish into a recruit and turns A Hero Lives into a copy of Mask Change. Also pitches to Allure. A fine role-players. It's just too bad it's not a D-Hero. Spell Striker - An oft-forgotten tech from days passed, this little guy is great as a ROTA target to help build your link summons. Ash Blossom - Best hand trap. PSZ - We don't play synchros, but he still fills an important role by putting things back into the deck (*cough* Malicious *cough*) and by enabling an easy link or Plasma. Spells: Allure & D-Draw - Our filter. Staple cards and one of the best reasons to run the D-Hero package. Just try not to get your D-Draw Ash'd! A Hero Lives - Excellent enabler for the deck, grabbing either Stratos for a recruit or Shadow Mist for Mask Change, and then allowing a normal summon follow up into a link. Fusion Destiny - Our primary Predeplant target. Pot of Avarice - The deck fills it's GY so fast that I'd be hard-pressed not to include this. One of the more frequent Dark Angel targets. Mask Change - Insane synergy with the deck. Dark Law is an absurd card and having access to it is one of this decks biggest strengths. Also combos with Cross-Sheep. Mask Change II - I wanted more Mask Change! Super Poly - Great Predeplant target and also enables more fusion for us. Divine Sword - Phoenix Blade - The best Isolde target since you can rebuy it to get a free card! Also our primary enabler for Dystopia. Linking Isolde into Anaconda for Dystopia is a great way to swing board advantage in your favor. ROTA, Foolish, Reborn, Impert - Staples. Extra deck: Dominance - Our primary target for Fusion Destiny. Lets us set up our GY heavily and mess with what our opponent draws, as well as giving us an insane board presence to OTK with after he dies. Dystopia - A backup Fusion Destiny target and a frequent Super Poly target. Dangerous - Tertiary fusion target. More of an enabler than a closer. Dark Law - The GOAT Divine Wind - Gives us a Mask target for Stratos, and a pretty good card in it's own right. Anki - Masked Change II target for Malicious and Dark Law, plus a good closer (especially with Honest Neos!) Fusion Dragon & Mud Dragon - Super Poly enablers. Borrelsword - OTK machine. Cerberus - Utility slot, can be whatever you like. Cross Crusader - Rarely needed, but extremely useful for getting your weaker hands off the ground. Isolde, Cross-Sheep, Anaconda - Our decks primary link engines.

deck_excerpt: Rouge deck that will give your opponent anxiety.
deck_description:
The Kaiju archetype is infamous for its ability to provide cheap and generic monster removal while bypassing almost any protection the target may have. So what if we'll build a deck that focuses on kaiju's strong point and enforcing it's weak point with control cards. At first glance this deck does not look like it will be able to compete with today's meta, but trust me it'll surely make your opponent be scared of setting up his board since it will just get destroyed. Most of the cards in this deck are power cards, as it can change the pace of the game with just one card, what more if you'll play multiple copies of it? This deck doesn't really have a combo and from the look of the card you'll know what it can do. So in order to utilize it more you need to study your opponent's deck in advance, that way. As you can see this can go either first or second turn depending on your opponent, but most of the time you'll want to go 1st to maximize inspector boarder. Side Deck Cards Purposes:
  • Droll & Lock Bird - Pretty good to side against combo decks like HERO, Infernoble, etc.
  • Harpie's Feather Duster - use this against backrow decks then they'll concede.
  • Twin Twister - same with the harpie's feather duster but they'll still continue the game.
  • Mystic Mine - Good for stopping your opponent while you gather resources.
  • Super Polymerization - OP board breaker!!!!
  • Dimensional Barrier - Probably the most OP side as of now, can literally make your opponent not play in their turn.
  • Imperial Order - Good against spell reliant decks like sky striker, HERO, etc.
  • Soul Drain - Since GY reliant deck is still a thing, use this so they can't play.
  Things to remember:
  • I know Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon is a thing but with this deck, it's just an another monster to be tributed.
  • Don't force to end the game quickly if you don't have enough resources, remember this a control deck.
  • Use fairy tail luna's effect on your opponent's one of monsters (monsters that only have one copy in their deck/extra deck)
  • ALWAYS CHECK YOUR RESOURCES

deck_excerpt: A "Gogogo" deck, which mainly uses Rock monsters and the support of various archetypes to spam Xyz monsters.
deck_description:
This is my take at a "Gogogo" deck. "Gogogos" as a deck strategy are somewhat rare nowadays, since they are simply included into "Onomato" decks in small numbers most of the time. To make the deck running more efficiently, I added quite a few other archetypes to the mix, making this more of a "Gogogo and Friends" list. The "Gogogos" aim, just like the rest of the "Onomato"-related archetypes, to bring out Xyz monsters and work with their effects and often use the "Utopia" cards as their boss monster or game ending options.

In terms of classic "Gogogo" cards, I run one "Gogogo Goram" (solid beater and a slow "Foolish Burial" in monster form), one "Gogogo Giant" (revives "Gogogo" monsters upon being Normal Summoned), one "Gogogo Gigas" (self-reviving monster options which does cost your Battle Phase and is therefore most useful going first), two "Gogogo Aristera & Dexia" (defensive option with an effect that can potentially take care of big beaters on the opposing board) and one copy of "Gogogo Golem - Golden Form" (potentially sizeable stat block with in-built monster effect negation). There are also quite a few "Onomato" cards in the deck which are very helpful in terms of consistency and monster swarming. Those options are two "Dodododwarf Gogogoglove", two "Utopic Onomatopoeia" and one "Zubababancho Gagagacoat", which all have various effects allowing Special summoning from the hand or reviving either themselves or other monsters from the graveyard and therefore fetch a lot of usable monsters for Xyz summons. The three copies of "Onomatopaira" not only help setting up the graveyard but also fetch the right combination of cards, while I also added one copy of "Reinforcement of the Army" for the sole reason of searching for either "Utopic Onomatopoeia" or "Zubababancho Gagagacoat".

Other archetype that are part of the deck include a small "Koa'ki Meiru" engine, with mainly "Koa'ki Meiru Supplier" as a solid Special summon since it triggers upon losing any Rock monster, while one copy of "Koa'ki Meiru Overload", "Koa'ki Meiru Guardian" and "Koa'ki Meiru Wall" serve as disruption and can be easily summoned with "Ties of the Brethren". The added "Diamond Core of Koa'ki Meiru" can give destruction protection to your "Koa'ki Meiru" monsters, but they are mostly there to fetch copies of "Koa'ki Meiru Supplier" for the summon effect (which in turn also searches "Koa'ki Meiru" monsters). Aside from that I decided to run a small and inexpensive "Adamancipator" engine, with two copies each of "Adamancipator Analyzer", "Adamancipator Seeker" and "Adamancipator Signs", which further help accrue Xyz-able monsters onto the field.

The rest of the Main Deck really only features more support cards to make the deck run a little smoother. One copy of both "Barrier Statue of the Drought" and "Fossil Dyna Pachycephalo" are good targets to summon via "Ties of the Brethren" when going first and are also solid options to search and go into via your Normal Summon, since there are situation in which the Special summon block will hurt the opponent more than you. "Doki Doki" is there as setup and as a play-enabler, "Block Golem" is more of a niche option, but will transfer itself into exactly enough materials to start a Xyz summon and "Sentry Soldier of Stone" can revive itself with relative ease, but can only be used for Link summons due to its level. One copy of both "Raigeki" and "Harpie's Feather Duster" seemed pretty much mandatory to me in the deck and are options you can play if the removal cards in the Extra Deck cannot be used. "Foolish Burial" is more graveyard setup while "Monster Reborn" is the obvious choice in terms of monster revival.

The Extra Deck features a number of options to work with and is the main focus of the deck. "Tornado Dragon" is solid backrow removal, "Castel the Skyblaster Musketeer" is non-destruction removal, "Diagusto Emeral" is a card draw option and "Gagaga Cowboy" can be used to inflict the last tick of damage. The aforementioned "Utopia" engine comes in form of two copies of "Number 39: Utopia", which can be used to summon either "Number S39: Utopia the Lightning" (for a 5000 ATK beater against monsters) or "Number 39: Utopia Double" (for a 10000 ATK beater with the single copy of "Double or Nothing!" in the main deck, but which I only included once due to consistency reasons for the rest of the deck). So far, there is nothing out of the ordinary and most players probably already knew of those cards prior to reading this section. "Number 55: Gogogo Goliath" might be less familiar and can serve as a DEF booster and recurrence tool, but mostly finds a way onto the board because it is a "Gogogo" monster and therefore triggers certain cards; "Gagagaga Magician" serves a similar purpose, but can revive previously used "Utopia" monsters for overlays and as 2500 ATK beaters. "Gallant Granite" is the Rock type searcher and therefore a very important tool of the deck. Lastly, the Link monsters in form of "Aussa the Earth Charmer, Immovable" and "Missus Radiant" both help getting cards upon being destroyed and both have solid effects that might come in handy during your turn ("Aussa the Earth Charmer, Immovable" being less useful with her revive effect, but "Missus Radiant" is a very solid tool since it provides solid stat boosts to pretty much everything on your side of the field).

The "Gogogos" as a deck on their own really aged rather poorly, which is why I had to include so many other options. Nonetheless, if you want to play a deck that is capable of spamming Xyz monsters in a more Casual environment, I urge you to give the rocky monsters a go. Furthermore, if you want more information about the "Gogogos" and cards I did not feature in this deck list (or other archetypes for that matter), feel free to visit my blog under this link: https://cubiccreativity.wordpress.com/2020/02/16/archetype-analysis-gogogo/

deck_name: Marincess but made by a Italian with a thing for Traptrix
deck_excerpt: Marincess but made by an Italian who has a thing for plants in the shape of girls
deck_description: Here we go again, my friends. I've made another weird deck. Today, we have Marincess' with a Traptrix engine. I know, that sounds wild; i'll elaborate as we go on. First of all, for the deck, we have the basic Marincess combo pieces. Nothing out of the ordinary, you just normal one and then activate some effects to special out the others. Although, here's where this deck differs; we have a small Traptrix engine. With Bottomless Trap Hole and Trap Hole Nightmare both at 3 in the deck, you have a strong backrow to stop the opponent's plays. You also have Myrmeleo to search out traps and pop backrow, Genlisea to help build backrow (note you'll most likely be using her in turn 3, after using a trap hole and sending it to the graveyard), and Mantis to search out the rest. We also have Marincess Battle Ocean, for the Marincess'. We now go into the extra deck. We have Sera, in case you want to do a bit more with the traps, but that's not the focus. You'll want to start using the Traptrix and Marincess' to link climb, and go into Great Bubble Reef. once you have Great Bubble Reef, you'll want to banish cards for the draw and attack gain, and go in for an OTK. Note: You'll want to go first, to set up your traps and such. As always, this is one of my first decks here, so any feedback is appreciated. Have a good day!

deck_excerpt: Hand rip water synchro
deck_description: The main goal of the deck is to go into needlefiber, ultimaya, or a powerful synchro after using "Awakening of the Possessed - Gagigobyte" to rip cards out of your opponents hand (possibly having an extra water monster and setting Spiritual Water Art - Aoi  The main way to play is to normal summon diva, go into Neptabyss, send goon, add/summon lappis, summon Anima, then go into Gagigobyte. After this you will end up with 2 lv 5 water monsters (1 being a tuner) that can go into Needlefiber (or ultimaya if on a budget).  You really want to normal summon Deep sea diva or go into Neptabyss some how  There is also the synchron engine which works great with the low lv water monsters as well as the frog engine for back up plays (easy lv 4 and 5 synchro plays)  Quite customizable (don't want to draw lappis, Neptabyss, or Gagigobyte so I recomend playing around 45 cards)  The main win conditions are Herald of the Arc Light (easy 2 make with all the lv 2s) and whatever you can make off of Needlefiber or Ultimaya  Junk Synchron works great in the deck and can easily go into lv 5 synchros  I play the nemeses engine to return all the banished monsters from Ronin, Aria, or Aqua Spirit

deck_description: Deck Style: Control , Combo  Main Attribute, Type : Water, Cyberse  The strategy of the deck is to go first in a "protect the castle" style that utilizes either a Marincess Battle Ocean summoned Marincess Wonder Heart or Marincess Great Bubble Reef, often accompanied by interaction offered from the small synchro toolbox. Disruption and protection comes in the form of cards such as Marincess Wave and White Howling in order to supplement the deck's boss monsters. 3 Moray of Greed can be replaced as flex slots (Handtraps are a good alternative).

deck_excerpt: Rokket Dragoon Link for Oct 2020
deck_description: Rokket list updated for Oct. 2020. Not much has changed, still running the Garden Rose Maiden through Apollousa route. It's nice, since it makes Apollo early in the turn, and you can play to your whole board with just one tuner extender. I'm back on a second Striker Dragon, since it helps when playing through interruptions. The nice thing about Dragon link is you can abuse all the broken stuff in the format, Linkross, Halq, Dragoon even, maybe even Rusty, but you can also just play through the old combo routes effectively and make similar powerful boards, even if those get stopped. I still think Dragoon puts it up to another level - you're in a 3 hand trap situation a lot of the time, and even if you have them, and the right ones, and time them right, you still have to play on with way fewer cards in the hand, and often through a Dragoon. It's the best link 2, and since the deck is inclined to play more than 40 cards the risk of bricking isn't so bad - besides, if you see the fusion, you don't make Dragoon, or you just play the fusion.  The hawtnezz in this deck is the Artifact engine. Lancea is okay right now, good enough to main with the engine, but the real goal here is to set up Tracer alongside Unchained Abomination in your normal combos to pop Scythe on their turn (Rokket Tracer pops somethings, triggers A-Bomb, A-Bomb pops Scythe).  You can only run 1 of the bricks if you want to, but they're way less bricky at 2 since you can just use them in normal combos. I wouldn't run a 40 card deck for Rokkets anymore, personally. I understand why people want the best possible odds of seeing their important cards, but you can often actually improve your odds of seeing a TYPE of card but running multiples of the TYPE of card in a larger deck. In Rokkets in particular, you have so many amazing extenders you want to be able to abuse, and you want the highest possibility of seeing those extenders as possible - yes, you see your one card combo less often, but you combo off just as often, and through interruptions more often. It puts a strain on the hand trap line, only the best of the best here.  In terms of the side deck, I decided to run obligatory back-row removal and hand traps, to help more effectively tailor against the combo decks at the front of the meta. Token Collector is here mostly for Infernoble, but is good against virtually any dedicated Linkross/Auroradon combo deck, and so it has fringe applications. Effect Veiler is here for Verte Anaconda, vs Dragoon decks, and also to cut Triple Tactics going second or Lancea against bad matchups. Ghost Ogre is here because it is really effective against Lost World in particular. It has niche uses, and is great against Field Spells in general, and you can bump up your hand traps in the mirror with it, because it is really good against Romulus most of the time.  Added Tempest into the deck. You need a good target to send with Dragon Ravine and still extend into Verte Anaconda in certain multiple hand trap situations, especially with Droll and Nibiru heavy in the meta right now.  Cut Tempest. It doesn't do it's job well enough. I also cut Dragoon, although that's more to test the deck without it, and improve the hand trap game. This means 1 fewer interruption you can play through, but the combo is essentially the same, and now there's room for Borrelsword, who is situationally useful in combos and under Guarddragons, and gives the deck an alternative for going second to Dragoon. I do like having more space for hand traps, I feel pretty solid on this line-up, for the meta.

deck_excerpt: Control based Simorgh deck with a small Lyrilusc engine for consistency boosting and raising the deck's ceiling.
deck_description: Deck Style: Control  Main Attribute, Type: Wind, Winged-beast  The strategy of the deck is to go first and spam the board with Simorgh and Lyrilusc monsters to create Simorgh, Bird of Sovereignty as soon as possible. Utilize one of two possible first turn locks such as (Apex Avian + Barrier Statue) or (Dark Simorgh + Anti-Spell) to slow down the game state. The Wincon comes from Sovereignty's effect to snowball advantage with high attack boss monsters and potentially OTK the following turn. 3 Trade-in can be swapped for Pot of Extravagance (The Extra Deck would need to be adjusted however).

deck_excerpt: Odd-Eyes, Metalfoes, Performapals, and Magicians. The ultimate Histlander pendulum deck!
deck_description: Learn about Histlander The idea behind the deck is to run basically every good Pendulum engine that's legal in these years. The deck can flexibly create/break boards and put out huge amounts of damage. We do run 40 cards due to not wanting to draw the Metalfoes Spells/Traps and so we can fit all the best engines. Pros: - Able to put up multiple negates with ease - Can OTK very easily, even if your board gets broken - Wide variety of different boards to address different matchups (Dweller, Rafflesia, or Vortex to name a few) Cons: - If your scales get destroyed, many hands can't properly recover - The lack of Links means you can't make explosive pend summon comebacks - You do run a fair amount of bricks and sometimes you just open unplayable hands.

deck_excerpt: 40 Card Fairy Tail Snow centric mill deck
deck_description: Learn about Histlander Much like TCG version of Snowsworn, the focus is on filling your Graveyard to fuel Fairy Tail Snow, using a combination of a Zombie engine and various R4NK engines to build a board. The deck can flex between board-building and grinding with Snow. Pros: - Has a very high turn 1 ceiling for board-building - Fairy Tail Snow can shut down many decks - Very flexible Extra Deck toolbox gives a good matchup spread Cons: - The ceiling of the deck is facilitated by a large number of cards you don't ever really want to draw - A lot of the deck's power can often be reliant on random mills, dropping consistency - Since the boards don't really put up negations, aggro decks can often break your board going 2nd with the right hand

Ratios can be adjusted in order to incorporate other extenders (such as Fire Flint Lady).

deck_excerpt: This deck focuses on blinding 2nd and OTKing your opponent, while still having a relatively strong opening going first (compared to other OTK decks)
deck_description: This deck is built for going 2nd and mainly uses Frightfur and Shaddoll cards to clear your opponents board and OTK while digging further through your deck with the Fluffal engine and also chain block important effects in order to swing the game in your favour. Going 1st your set up board can vary from an Abyss Dweller + True King of all Calamities + El Shaddoll Winda to fewer combinations of them. The profile is also very budget focussed. (if playing on a budget isn't a thing for you, pure Dinosaur would be the going 2nd Deck to look after) Card ratios Monsters: 3 Fluffal Bear because it starts your draw engine (mostly based on Toy Vendor) and can get you a Poly back (which doesn't come up that seldom because I only play 2 copies);  1 Fluffal Penguin because you can't always use it as Fusion Material (often you use Fluffal Cat in order to get your Poly back); 1 Fluffal Cat because it more ore less duplicates your Poly in a way; 3 Fluffal Dog and 1 Fluffal Dolphin (or 2 Fluffal Dog 2 Fluffal Dolphin) this ratio is debateable because Dolphin+ Foolish Burial Goods + any Fluffal starts your Draw engine (and might get you a Poly back to the deck) but Fluffal Dog + Fluffal Bear also starts your draw engine; 1 Fluffal Wings because you only use the draw effect and want to send it to your graveyard in any way rather than having it in your starting hand; 1 Fluffal Owl because space is limited and King of the Swamp searches Poly without being summoned; 2 Edge Imp Chain because the effect is very good but only in combination with other cards ( f.e. when you search it with Frightfur Patchwork and got a Fluffal you insantly have access to the Frightfur part of your Extra Deck, you might also play 3 though); 1 Edge Imp Sabres because it is easily searchable and the effect comes up very seldom; 1 of Shaddoll Beast/ Dragon/ Hedgehog and Naelshaddoll Ariel for drawing/ hitting backrow/ searching a Shaddoll to discard or fuison with/ clearing your opponents graveyard (can't be triggered by Toy Vendor/ Super Poly or other cards that discard for cost!); 2 King of the Swamp for searching your Poly (or to replace Edge Imp Sabres) you might also replace it with 1 additional Poly and 1 additional Edge Imp Chain ( drawing the stated card is better than searching it if you are likely to face negation); 1 Dinowrestler Pankratops as it can easily force out negations going 2nd Spells: 3 Frightfur Patchwork because it's an insane searcher; 3 Foolish Burial Goods because it can send Toy Vendor (and therefore search) and also Frightfur Repair (if you absolutely need a Edge Imp/ Fluffal specialed from your hand); 2 Polymerization becaused it can be searched and recycled ( 3 also would be an option if you are facing a lot of negation against your search); 1 Frightfur Fusion because it is a searchable extender but you don't want it in your opening hand; 2 Toy Vendor because you want to send it to the GY or set it with Fluffal Bear but not draw it (1 would be too less copies, 3 use too much Main Deck space in my opinion); 1 Frightfur Repair as you want to send it with Frightfur Cruel Whale but not draw it ( it's a good extender but not more as that); 3 Shaddoll Fusion because it generates a lot of advantage going 2nd  if you are facing an opponent using the Extra Deck (if not you rather side out all copies of this card); 3 Super Polymerization because it's a cheap and reliable going 2nd card ( can only be stopped by an Extra Deck or Spell Card lock, you might also keep it in the Side Deck and replace it with 2 Dark Hole 1 Raigeki as these have broader ways of usage but are easily negated) and also triggers a discarded Toy Vendor etc. ; 1 Mind Control because it's often a must negate going 2nd Extra Deck: 1 True King of all Calamities as going 1st option (Fluffal Dog + Frightfur Patchwork get you there in 4 summons if uninterrupted); Abyss Dweller as going 1st option; 1 Predaplant Dragostapelia/ Starving Venom Fusion Dragon/ Mudragon of the Swamp for your Super Poly targets; 1 El Shaddoll Shekhinaga/ Construct/ Winda for: negation/untargeted destruction an Fluffal Wings in the graveyard/ floodgate and also filling your graveyard; 1 Cross-Sheep ( this spot is debateable but I like it for linking off a Mind Control target/ getting into Abyss Dweller); 1 Frightfur Kraken/ Sabre-Tooth/ Tiger/ Wolf for breaking boards and OTKing   Side Deck and noteable mentions The side deck is more an idea of cards that can be good siding in or even in the Main Deck e.g. El Shaddoll Apkallone + Extra-Foolish Burial can search El Shaddoll Fusion ( here I also included expensive cards but side decks quickly change from format to format). Your real Side Deck should definitely contain: cards against backrow oriented Decks (Twin Twister, Anti-Spell-Fragrance); cards against heavy combo Decks (Dark Ruler no more, Nibiru); cards to side in if you are likely to be forced to go 1st ( Floodgates, Extenders);(I put Apollousa in here because it can replace Calamities if it gets banned in the future); replacing Mudragon of the Swamp with Borreload Dragon might make sense for facing sticky monsters with high protection capabilities; If you have the PSY-Frame package in your Main or Side Deck you should probably play PSY-Framelord Lamda General discussion and  strategies Pros: The deck can play through 1 hand Trap mostly and has a lot of easy accessable removal options; The Fluffal draw engine can often ''unbrick'' your hand and draw into your Side Deck cards in game 2 and 3; The deck leaves a lot of Main deck space to be sided out because the Shaddoll half of the deck is not mandatory (e.g. if you are facing an opponent who doesn't use the Exra Deck at all you are better off taking out your 7 card Shaddoll engine and replacing it with Side Deck equalizers); the deck can also bait negations without committing to a normal or special summon (f.e. Toy Vendor or Frightfur Patchwork search effect, going 2nd blow out cards); Chain Blocking is often an option in order to assure your important effects to go through; going 1st you can set up boards in under 5 summons (which means you don't have to fear Nibiru, the Primal Being) Cons: The deck is very susceptible to Hand Traps ( searches a lot and uses on-field monster effects); The deck highly Extra Deck and Graveyard reliant; the Shaddoll half of the deck only works against Extra Deck strategies; the deck's intrinsic removal options are mostly targeting and destructing ( Frightfur Cruel Whale is only destructing); The deck relies on its Spell Cards to go through; as many cards can be sided out (and have to in certain match-ups) a 15 card Side Deck is not capable of fitting all kind of cards you might need; the deck can brick going 1st (this rarely happens going 2nd though, apart of not drawing blow-out cards) Deck building As we now have stated strenghts and weaknesses of the deck, we have to find a way to minimize the weaknesses while not cutting too much of its strenghts. Going 1st Hand Traps put a lot of pressure on this deck (especially Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring, Droll & Lock Bird), which can be decreased by playing Called by the Grave + 3 PSY-Framegear Gamma + the 1 PSY-Frame Driver (as you can generate a lot of advantage before committing to a summon Gamma will be live). Also activating Gamma and then linking off the Driver with another monster into Lamda lets you search another copy of Gamma in the End Phase (which you are now free to activate even with monsters on board); Infinite Impermanence stays a card you have to play around -->this package is a Side Deck option for both going 1st and 2nd As non-target removal I would recommend to play Borreload Dragon (you have to play Cross-Sheep for Link-Climbing reasons, if you decide to go this route), either Mudragon of the Swamp or Predaplant Dragostapelia should be exchanged. As the deck is Spell Card reliant, big threats are cards like: Secret Village of the Spellcasters, Imperial Order or mono Spell negates. Against the Floodgates side in 3 Evenly Matched (very versatile card in general) and maybe 1 Red Reboot (also a killer against trap-based backrow decks). Mono negates can be overrolled by simply playing more board wipers ( 2 Dark Hole 1 Raigeki instead of 3 Super Polymerization). One might also play Super Polymerization in he Side Deck with Starving Venom Fusion Dragon as it's only target in order to fit in Cross-Sheep + Borreload Dragon + PSY-Framelord Lamda (or maybe even replace Super Poly with Dark Ruler no More and gain another free Extra Deck spot); playing Frightfur Wolf is also debateable, but it's synergy with Frightfur Cruel Whale to bump it up to 3000 ATK speaks for holding an Extra Deck slot for it

deck_excerpt: Loptr makes Rikka have 12 starters. With 1 other plant in hand, we can easily put 2 interruptions and able to run big staple slot, sounds familiar? Ye
deck_description: What a year. TCG with combo and OCG with control. Only a deck with big staple slot can survive the format. So we cut all the Rikka extender for more staple slot and starter, except Loptr. With Mardel, Loptr acts the same as Petal making us have 12 starters (3 Loptr, 3 Petal, 3 Glamour, 2/3 Lonefire, and One for One). Combo needs 1 other plant in hand, so it's a 2 cards combo (similar to Zoodiac that needs Ramram in GY). Normal summon the starter, add Snowdrop (can add others like Mudan if you already have Snowdrop), Snowdrop will ss the other plant we have on hand by tributing the starter, and since we only run plant monsters that searches (Mardel, Mudan, Lonefire, Petal), we can easily ss Mudan for Rikka spell/trap like Sheet. Last play is using Snowdrop eff to make all plant lv8 for Teardrop, making us have 2 interruptions with Sheet. In the end you'll realise we only use exactly 2 cards to do the stuff, the negs are covered by the amount of plus from the plants we run.  If going second, any plant extender (One for One, Rose Girl, or the new Ingunar) can result you Fairy Knight Ingunar (board bounce, spell speed 4) since Snowdrop can target Mudan making all plant becomes lv6. Plenty of room for side deck cards too.  Main deck: 12 Starters, 2 Mardel (ensures Loptr resolving, not really a brick since Snowdrop can summon it, and most importantly, plus), 1-2 Snowdrop (the heart and soul, but you don't wanna draw double of this, 2 cus we play Desires), 1-2 Mudan (Sheet grind game, arguably worse than Snowdrop cus Snowdrop makes Teardrop), Rose Girl (or any plant extender, I choose it cus it has recovery, super clutch with Rikka Petal playstyle). The rest is just staples and draw cards for more consistency (Desires similar to Salamangreat, but we run 2 Mudan/Snowdrop while Gazelle is at 1).  Extra Deck: 2 Teardrop (can play 3 if you want since there aint many plant extra deck around, needs 3 Snowdrop tho), Peryton (Snowdrop targets Mardel), Ingunar (3 lv6 mats, explained above), Princessprite (just another plant extra deck we can make, plus if it mills s/t), Jasmine (for link climbing if aint locked to plant), Verte (generic plant link, helps handtrap like Nibiru and Psy-Frame to become plant, can run Super Poly too but too many Dragon Buster lock around), Negalogia (super situational if not plant locked), Halq (we run tuner handtrap, can put Selene too if with Effect Veiler), Link Spider (helps Psy-Frame Driver and Nibiru token for Verte).  Pros: Super consistent, have follow-up, big staple slot.  Cons: Weaker payoff than Zoodiac, prone to handtrap.

deck_excerpt: True Draco meta deck - Counter of the post september 2020 banlist meta.
deck_description: Pretty simple to play, go first and set a lot of disruptions. The main strength of the deck is its ability to adapt to its opponents using its side. HOW TO SIDE: Go first: -Swap "Infinite Impermanence" with "Solemn Judgment".                 -Switch floodgates depending of your opponent's deck.                 -Use "Cosmic Cyclone" against backrow decks". Go second: -Keep "Infinite Impermanence".                      -Use "Evenly matched" to wipe boards.                      -Use "Dark Ruler no More" against boards full of negates(Dragon Link)/Tower monsters (Dragun). Don't hesitate to put out "Upstart Gobelin" or "Into the Void" if you need to put in a lot of cards.

deck_excerpt: Synchron Quasar spam for Histlander Modern
deck_description: Learn about Histlander Making a comeback from the 5Ds era, a combination of the Synchron Extreme Structure Deck cards with the 5Ds Legendary Collection gives access to a huge pool of cards for spamming Synchros. Pros: - Has many hands that can break through boards when going second as easily as it builds boards going first - Very high ceiling including both handlooping and negates from Shooting Quasar - Lots of high powered bombs that can be drawn into semi-consistently Cons: - Combos are very complex and can be difficult to learn - If your board is broken there is a very low chance of recovery - Due to the necessity for a high density of extenders, you don't have a lot of room for generic cards

deck_excerpt: Go through half of your deck in one turn 👍
deck_description: Again, I was browsing decks in the "Flower Cardian" archetype. Most of the decks were either incomplete or just used this as a support archetype. I can tell you this deck should NEVER be a support archetype. This deck not only is a field swarm deck, it is also a card game INSIDE OF A CARD GAME.  There is really no one strategy for this deck. The only things you have to watch out for when playing with this deck is your Tuners. That goes without being said for any Synchro deck, however there are scenarios where I've accidentally had 3 different Tuners out at a time.  Most of the time this deck has a plan B, C, and D when playing with it. There is always a way to recover or stall until your next turn.

deck_excerpt: Lightsworn Infernoid that focuses on filling the Graveyard and repeatedly board-breaking
deck_description: Learn about Histlander We run every Infernoid and as much R4NK and self-mill as possible to fill the Graveyard and fuel big Infernoid plays. Pros: - Lots of Extra Deck flexibility with the R4NK toolbox - Lots of board-breaking potential with the big Infernoids - Tons of explosive draws such as Reasoning, Soul Charge, and Instant Fusion Cons: - Heavily reliant on RNG mills - Can struggle to actually OTK due to the level restrictions of the Infernoids - Can have some difficulty grinding due to the highlander nature of the deck

deck_excerpt: Casual Rank 10 engine primarily utilizing Egyptian God's True Name with Convulsion of Nature and other cards to call the top of deck correctly.
deck_description: Two main plays are to spam out a rank 10, and use top of deck calls for card advantage.  The Level 10 materials for XYZ are: Obelisk from a True Name, Exodius via its own condition, Metal Reflect Slime with a possible stop at Egyptian god slime now that that's a thing, and Accel (sending Quickdraw to up its level) made out of Deep Sea Diva and Gishki Diviner. From there you have a simple choice of Number XX, Gustav into Liebe, Galaxy Destroyer. Accel and Quickdraw can also make a Cyber Dragon Infinity.  Plays with Reckless Summon are for Diva into triple Diviner for draw 3 and Trish Zero, or for triple quickdraw into CDI and maybe a Chevalier De Fleur for the extra negate.  The card calling is mostly True Name for the quick Obelisk, or Sphere Mode if your opponent has troublesome cards that need to be cleared. Diviner and Archfiend's Oath can generate extra cards in hand, especially with Oath being a soft once per turn. Convulsion, Card Advance, Spellbook Organization, and Diviner can be used for either a peek at the card before it's called or even a top of deck fix before calling.

deck_excerpt: Generaider Numeron hybrid
deck_description: Eternity Code gave Generaiders their version of 2020's "every deck gets an omni-negate"-treatment in form of Harr and a huge consistency boost with Loptr. Couple that with a handful of handtraps and that alone can be enough to slow down current meta decks on a good day. Similar can be said about Zexal Turbo Numeron. Number S0: Utopic Zexal can lock you opponent down for a turn but he's weak during your turn and falls to Gamma and Infinite Impermanence. Still, with the right amount of handtraps you just might be lucky enough to win. Ideally you make your Numeron plays and then switch Numeron Gate for Generaider Boss Stage. During your opponents Draw Phase you summon Harr from your deck or, if Harr is in hand, summon Dovelgus and then chain his effect on his summon, tributing himself to summon Harr from hand. DON'T activate Zexal in the same chain. Once Harr is on the board you then proceed to activate Zexal's effect. Now if your opponent tries to activate Psy-Framegear Gamma or Infinite Impermanence you can negate that with Harr. Also don't forget to make use of Harr's second effect (which they wrote down first because who reads cards all the way to the end, yet I still keep forgetting about this effect) to force your opponent to send a monster from their hand or field to the GY if they add a card to their hand from their deck except for their normal draw.   Quickly some card choices explained: 1# Effect Veiler can be swapped for Infinite Impermanence (Less of a card choice and more of a budget thingy) 2# No Memories of Hope. Albeit drawing 4 cards sounds incredible (realistically speaking 3 cards as you're trying to play around Nibiru. Numeron Gate 4 exists only to OTK) both archetypes don't require you to throw your entire hand to establish a board and therefore don't rely on draw power as much as other decks do. These slots find better use in handtraps. 3# No World Legacy Monstrosity/Trias Hierachia/Girsu Mekk-Knight. These cards are incredible in pure Generaider to summon V.F.D. turn 1 while also giving you an extra interruption/draw power with Trias but they don't add much practicality in a hybrid deck with less slots to spare. 4# Cyber Dragon Nova & Invoked Mechaba. You can fill these 2 ED slots as you like but I've been running into so many Dogmatika engines lately (and the only out to Winda would be Loptr's effect allowing to resolve) so I decided to skip the Side Deck and move them to the Extra Deck right away. 5# Generaider Boss Room. I added one copy of this card to search off of Mardel if you already have access to Generaider Boss Stage. This card is an omni negate if your opponents effect is chained to the activation of your Generaider card or effect. (Boss Room doesn't really negate the effect but rather changes the effect to both players drawing a card which can be advantageous to you but also to your opponent, so keep that in mind)    Now go forth and get your game on.

deck_excerpt: The new tier 1 NIBIRU PROOF Infernoble Knight deck is here! Combos included!
deck_description: This is my latest Infernoble knight build and I think it is very consistent. Infernoble Knight is a tier 1 deck, being able to adapt to the current metagame and play through the ‘powerhouse handtraps’ such as gamma, imperm, nibiru and even droll and lock bird (this one requires a good hand). Playing 60 cards in Infernoble knight is absolutely necessary to avoid drawing bricks such as too many equip spells, combo tuners etc. For this build I am mainly focusing on playing NIBIRU PROOF, that would either be playing around nibiru or playing through it. I have included combos for both in my NIBIRU PROOF Infernoble knight combos, I recommend that you check it out - you can watch some combos and learn how to play the deck better and improve as a player. If you do, please like the video and subscribe to the channel - it is a great way to support me and the channel. I will now go over what cards we need in hand and what the end boards are going to be in all the combos I show in my video. Also if you are interested in doing so - you may check out my other uploads on YGOPROdeck, I have uploaded a dragon link and 2 Eldlich decks and I have youtube videos explaining those as well, link to those can be found in the YGOPROdeck of those. If you have any questions regarding the deck, let me know in the comments below or the comments you youtube. Good luck and have fun!   REMINDER: ALL THE COMBOS THAT I SHOW HERE ARE SHOWN HOW TO ACHIVE AND EXPLAINED IN-DEPTH IN MY VIDEO Link to the video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGx6sROpxmw   Combo 1: Best case scenario   Cards needed in hand: any way to get 2 warrior monsters (neo space connector, submilation knight etc)   End Board: Charles with Oliver equipped, savage with 2 counters, herald and 1 hand rip from the opponent    Combo 2: Play through nibiru (I know it sounds crazy but it works!)   Cards needed in hand: Infernoble knight renud + a way to get 2 warriors to the field   End board: Charles with Oliver equipped, savage with 2 counters, herald and 1 hand rip from the opponent   Combo 3: Play around Nibiru (Gearfriend is OP)   Cards needed in hand: Infernoble knight ogier and Infernoble arms durandel   End Board: Savage with 3 counters, True King (aka free win), and 1 hand rip from opponent   Combo 4: Play around nibiru    Cards needed in hand: Infernoble knight ogier and Infernoble arms durandel   End Board: Savage with 3 counters, Charles with Oliver equipped, and 2 hand rips from opponent   REMINDER: ALL THE COMBOS THAT I SHOWED ABOVE ARE SHOWN HOW TO ACHIVE AND EXPLAINED IN-DEPTH IN MY VIDEO Link to the video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGx6sROpxmw Thank you and stay tuned for more!

deck_excerpt: Control based variant of Vampires with a small Zombie World engine to increase the deck's ceiling.
deck_description: Deck Style: Control, Combo  Main Attribute, Type: Dark, Zombie  The primary strategy of the deck is to go first and lock down the field though the use of Zombie World, Balerdroch, Vampire Domination, and other Floodgates. Super Poly and it's respective Extra Deck targets are used as additional pieces of disruption when going first, or board removal tools if forced to go second. The wincon of the deck tends to come from the Rivalry/Zombie World lock backed up by Balerdroch and an Extra Deck boss monster of your choice. Additional copies of Vampire Domination and Domain can be cut in order to fit in any combination of the various zombie support cards available (Allure of Darkness is a possible option but beware, as a handful of your monsters are not the Dark attribute).

deck_excerpt: With the Lost of Engage, Sky Striker still proves that it can compete with meta decks.
deck_description:
With the lost of Sky Striker Mobilize - Engage!, the deck's gameplay greatly change. Fortunately Sky Striker Mecha - Widow Anchor and Sky Striker Ace - Kagari came off the banlist, with these two back to 3, the deck will now be able to compete again with most of the meta decks. Handtraps Explanation:
  • Nibiru, The Primal Being - I've observed that most decks right now are abusing Halqifibrax, this card can easily change the flow of the game to your favor against those type of decks.
  • Ghost Ogre &  Snow Rabbit - Since Numeron is still a thing here in TCG, it will be wise to put this in the main deck just to be sure. Although you can still use this against some of your opponent's key card in order to interrupt their combo.
  • Droll & Lock Bird - I've noticed that most of the combo decks will not be bothered when you use Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring to them, so instead I've come to a decision that this handtrap will have a much more impact to your opponent's combo.
  • Effect Veiler - Self Explanatory handtrap. Most of you will say that Infinite Impermanence will be a better choice but since we have a Selene in the Extra Deck, this monster will be more useful overall.
Most of the Spell Cards are pretty much standard except Sky Striker Maneuver - Scissors Cross, I put this card in the Main Deck since Dragoon is a thing. This card can out your opponent's Dragoon, though that's not the effect that I use it most for. The thing that I like about this card is it helps me fill up my GY with Spell Cards faster. Extra Deck is pretty much standard except the Link Spider. You can use this card against Dino especially if they use Lost World, that card can lowkey shut down Sky Striker. Good thing we have this card to remove the token from our main monster zone. Side Deck Explanation:
  • Nibiru, The Primal Being - Good against combo deck. Side it in if your opponent greatly relies on combo and if they don't have that much extender or bait cards.
  • Dinowrestler Pankratops - Can pop your opponent's card and it's a free summon monster.
  • Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring - If you think Droll & Lock Bird is not a good choice against your opponent, side this in instead.
  • Dark Ruler No More - Good card to break your opponent's board. If you think that your Nibiru will just get negated or baited, side this in instead.
  • Cosmic Cyclone - Good against Altergeist and other backrow decks. This card will prevent the Altergeist's grind ability.
  • Mystic Mine - If you think your match will come to a grind one, side this in so that your opponent's pace will slow down.
  • Evenly Matched - Self Explanatory card. Use this with Dark Ruler No More and your opponent's face will be shocked.

deck_excerpt: Lost World Dinosaurs with a Kaiju engine splashed in!  (Watch the video for news on my 2021 video series)
deck_description: I found out from YouTube that Godzilla VS King Kong is going to air in 2021, assuming nothing goes wrong. And for the past few weeks, if not months, I have been getting back into Godzilla; I used to be a big fan back in middle school. So I made this Dinosaur Kaiju deck, named "Godzilla March", after Godzilla's iconic theme song.   Because of the Kaiju engine here, going second is more important than ever for Dinos. Interrupted Kaiju Slumber is one of the best cards in the deck, not just because it turns the tables if your opponent has multiple strong monsters on board, but because it works surprisingly well with Lost World. With Kaiju Slumber, you can give yourself a Dogoran and your opponent any other Kaiju, and Dogoran will be stronger, since the opponent's Kaiju is not a Dinosaur. Plus, you can do this before your Normal Summon so that your opponent will get a Juraegg Token and they can't target any non-tokens with card effects.   Slumber also has synergy with Lost World because you can use it while the opponent has a Juraegg Token to pop a Babycerasaurus or Petiteranodon, and then search an Oviraptor. And one last thing about this deck? Because Animadorned Archosaur is Level 1, the Extra Deck has 2 Relinquished Anima in there. If you are able to summon it, then summon a Kaiju to your opponent's field in the zone Anima points to, so that Anima can equip it.   As for the Side Deck, it contains 3 copies of cards that are all useful in the current meta. So if you're playing against a high-tier deck and it's time to get serious, just switch out the Kaiju cards for those.

deck_excerpt: Just my personal take on the Dark Magician deck for 2020, with a mix of Windwitch engine.
deck_description:
"So I have a few plans with this deck."

  • Plan 1:

    (Dark Magician Loop)

With this first plan it's to try and go for the Dark Magician's (DM) with, Dark Magical Circle (Circle) & Eternal Soul (Soul) ,to try to go for the Banish loop every turn with destroying DM and revivng him with with Soul and into the banish with Circle. If you dont have cards in hand just cycle through with Magicican's Souls (MGS') and or, Magician's Rod (MR), Soul Servant (SS), Illusion Magic (IM) or even Apprentice Illusion Magician (AIM). With the Deck you have plenty of search for DM I think more than enough to get any combo off.

If there are any road blocks on the field, its pretty easy to get rid of them when you have DM on the field with cards such as the Dark Burning Magic (DBM), and with the Soul, Circle combo on the field.

  • Plan 2:

    (WindWitches)

This plan is to try and get out Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon out on the field with the Windwitch engine. The special summon (Ss) Windwitch - Ice Bell (Ice Bell) into Windwitch - Glass Bell (Glass Bell) into Both Ice Bell & Glass Bell's effects. First Reducing oppents life by 500 giving the slight burn to your opponent using Ice Bell & with Glass Bell getting  Windwitch Snow Bell (Snow Bell) into your hand.

With Snow Bell in hand you can Ss Snow Bell onto the field through Snow Bells effect allowing it to be Ss to the field if you have 2 or more Wind Monsters, and no non-wind mosters; you can Ss from your hand to the field. With that set you can then Tune Glass Bell & Ice Bell into either the Clear Wing Synchro Dragon (Clear Wing) or the  Windwitch - Winter Bell (Winter Bell) .

Personally 90% of the time I will go into Winter Bell, because most of the time you are not keeping this part of the component long. With Winter Bell on the field activating its effect (Target 1 Windwitch monster in your GraveYard (GY) and inflict damage to your oppoent equal to that target's Level x200 during the battle phase).

Most the time I only use this effect. I usually Target the Glass Bell dealing the most effective amont of Damage to my opponet's life points giving them another slight burn.  After all that you can then Tune Snow Bell & Winter Bell (or Clear Wing, if you decide to go down that path) together to summon Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon. Once you have Crystal Wing out on the field, its usually a good enough wall of defence, attack and negates that it can help you in all stages of the match. I feel this combo is fairly effective when its pulled off.

When its not pulled off its a shame but I feel when you have cards such as Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring and Infinite Impermance in deck it helps negate most things that will stop you from pulling the combo off. But if there is too much struggle I have throw into the Side Deck the Effect Veiler, Droll & Lock Bird, and Twin Twisters to help with flexability.

  • Plan 3:

    (Dragun of Red-Eyes)

 Now this is the cheese king overlord so all you need for this plan is to as the tital say's. Get Dragun of Red-Eyes out onto the field. I have made it so there are a few ways of achiving this goal. First is the 2 Keeper of Dragon Magic's, If the card is normal or Special Summoned: You can discard 1 card; and add 1 Polymerization or Fusion Spell from deck to hand and reveal 1 fusion Monster (Being the Dragun of Red-Eyes in this case) in the extra deck; Ss 1 of the fusion materials listed from that monster from the GY in face-down defence postion.

But once you have done that, the Spell card you are after is 90% of the time Red-Eyes Fusion. You want to instantly pop this when there are no negates on the field and just summon Dragun of Red-Eyes right out.

Other ways of Summoning Dragun of Red-Eyes is to Link Summon PredaPlant Verte Anaconda (Verte) by having to effect monsters on the field and tributing them for Verte. Then popping Verte's Effect, to target 1 face-up monster on the field; it becoming Dark until the end of the current turn this effect is activated, then Paying 2000 Lp and sending a Fusion or Poly from the deck to the GY then the effect of the spell activates.

So you will usually use it to search for Red-Eyes Fusion to Summon Dragun of Red-Eyes.

"So there are 3 Simple combo's I use in this deck, there are a few more, but im sure most people could figure it out".

"Have fun ggwp" ~Buzm

deck_name: Shiranui Demon Slayers of Zombie World
deck_excerpt: If you love the anime "Demon Slayer," this is the deck for you! This deck combines the offensive/recursive power of "Shiranui" with the oppressive con
deck_description:
This is my own personal decklist that combines the offensive/recursive power of "Shiranui" with the oppressive control that "Zombie World Lock" offers. I thought I'd release this list for Halloween for the festivities. :) The main strategy of this deck is to establish the "Zombie World Lock" board.  While Zombie World + Rivalry of Warlords ensures that your opponent only controls only one monster on their field, Doomking Balerdroch allows a negate + banish once per turn. To achieve this board, Zombie World + Doomking have to be present on the field. This ideal board primarily falls to the crux combo piece Uni-Zombie. Uni-Zombie almost single-handedly achieves this end board by milling zombies from the hand or deck (Necroworld Banshee for Zombie World) (Glow-Up Bloom for Doomking), in addition to providing synchro access. The primary ways to search out Uni-Zombie is through Shiranui Solitaire, and Shiranui Solitaire can also be accessed by Ghost Meets Girl - A Shiranui's Story. The Non-Archetypal Zombies add some muscle into this deck through their various interactions with big Daddy Doomking: Jack-O-Bolan is a free summon which helps mill your hand to your graveyard for plays. It provides a quick effect monster reborn once per turn, which also trigger Doomking's banishment effect - resulting in an interruption and a extra zombie on board. Vampire Fraulein is a zombie battlephase handtrap that summons itself when an attack is declared, allowing Doomking to banish during the battlephase. It also adds up to +3000 ATK/DEF to any zombie monster on the field, once per battle (for the cost of lifepoints), turning any zombie into a massive beatstick. (Link 2) Vampire Sucker provides more resources to a zombie player by giving the player a free draw anytime a zombie is resurrected from either graveyard. During the standby phase, if Doomking is in the graveyard and there is a Field Spell on the board, it will resurrect itself, which prompts Vampire Sucker's +1 draw effect (chain link 1) and Doomking's banishment effect (chain link 2). Drawing one card and banishing another on the field/graveyard in the standby phase is often devastating. Often in the first turn, Doomking + another zombie is linked away for Vampire Sucker to allow for this chain to occur during your opponent's standby phase. Non-archtypal synchros are also useful in this deck. For unprepared decks, , (LVL12 Synchro)Geomathmech Final Sigma is invincible since it is unaffected by card effects while in the EMZ (this card is easy to bring out by synchroing a level 4 uni-zombie with a (level 8) Doomking, and Doomking returns in opponent's standby phase.) , (LVL7 Synchro)F.A Dawn Dragster is a OPT S/T negate. , (LVL8 Synchro)Draco Berserker punishes every effect used by the opponent by with banishement and (LVL8 Synchro)Psy-Framelord Omega is banished pile recursion and interruption. Non-Archetypal Spell/Traps: Gold Sarcophagus - Triggers every maindeck Shiranui banishment effect. (Solitaire = Resurrection from banished pile) ( Samurai = Recovery from graveyard) (Spiritmaster = 1 pop). Monster Reborn - Pretty straightforward. Also trigger's Vampire Sucker's effect. Pot of Desires - +2 draw for 10 cards banished face-down. Remember Shiranui monsters banished facedown don't trigger their effects! Careful about using this card too much, it may banish too many combo pieces. Terraforming/Metaverse - Access to Zombie World.

Rivalry of Warlords - Forces both players to only control 1 type of monster.When they Summon any monster, Zombie World changes that monsters type to Zombie. Rivalry of Warlord's will prevent that player from attempting to summon any other monster that is not a Zombie Type monster. Therefore, unless the opponent is playing a zombie deck, they cannot summon from their hand, deck, or extra deck if they have zombies on their field. Zombie World + Rivalry of Warlords + Doomking Balerdroch makes a very difficult to break board. This card cannot be searched in this deck, only drawn.

Super Polymerization becomes a very powerful board breaker/interruption with zombie world, as almost any monster on the field can be fused away for Dragonecro Nethersoul Dragon. Mudragon and Starving Venom Dragon are also Super Poly targets. The Shiranui portion of the deck provides various helpful effects for the deck: Shiranui Solitaire allows more ready access to the "ZWorld Lock" board, by searching Uni-Zombie from deck. Solitaire also allows for recursion from the banished pile by reborning any banished Shiranui (except itself) when the card is banished. Shiranui Samurai is a one of, since it's searchable and isn't a combo piece. It's main strength is it's quick effect, allowing Doomking to trigger it's effect anytime during the opponent's turn. It can also out monsters that are hard to get rid of through it's banishment effect. It's also recursion as it allows graveyard recovery when it's banished. Shiranui Spiritmaster allows for a target destruction of a card on the field anytime it's banished face-up with cards such as Shiranui Samurai, Shiranui Style Swallow's Slash, Gold Sarcophagus, etc. Shiranui Spectralsword can tune in the field and graveyard. Through graveyard synchro, it can cheat out Archfiend Zombie-Skull even without the use of proper materials. Shiranui Style Swallow's Slash is targeted destruction for two monsters in exchange for a zombie tribute, and it also banishes a Shiranui from deck, triggering their effects. If Shiranui Spiritmaster is banished, 3 cards on the field are destroyed. (+ it sounds like a special move from Demon Slayer lol, extra cool points) Ghost Meets Girl, a Shiranui's Story provides extra access to combo pieces since it searches out Shiranui Solitaire which in turns accesses Uni-Zombie. Shiranui Extra Deck monsters are this deck's main offensive juggernauts - (LVL5 Synchro) Swordsaga changes battle position, (LVL7 Synchro) Squiresaga provides non-targeting destruction, (LVL8 Synchro) Shogunsaga boosts it own attack on summon for OTKs, and Sunsaga/Skillsaga provide blanket protection, destruction and recovery. While this deck is strong and semi-consistent going first, it doesn't do well to interruptions, negates and handtraps. If Uni-Zombie is somehow negated, the turn usually ends there. This deck also has difficulty breaking boards, as it doesn't have much tools to do so. All in all, this deck is a fun rogue strategy to play, semi-budget, and easy to learn. Have fun and Happy Halloween duelists!

deck_excerpt: Salamangreat Deck Profile With Combo Tutorial
deck_description: The Yu-Gi-Oh! Trading Card Game Known as the Yu-Gi-Oh! Official Card Game (遊☆戯☆王オフィシャルカードゲーム, Yū-Gi-Ō Ofisharu Kādo Gēmu) in Asia, is a Japanese collectible card game developed and published by Konami. It is based on the fictional game of Duel Monsters created by manga artist Kazuki Takahashi, which is the main plot device during the majority of the manga franchise, Yu-Gi-Oh, and its various anime adaptations and spinoff series. "Salamangreat" (転生炎獣サラマングレイトSaramangureito) is an archetype of FIRE Cyberse monsters used by Theodore Hamilton (Soulburner) in Yu-Gi-Oh! VRAINS. The "Salamangreat" monsters are based on fiery themed animals. And while the Main Deck members appear to be based on small and average-sized animals, the Extra Deck members are based on the largest and most majestic of the animal kingdom. Much like Yusaku's animal-based Cyberse monsters, "Salamangreats" are armored with a cyberspace design. They also have a hot-red tint spread over their bodies and are constantly emitting flames.  If you have any questions you can chat with me in my channel  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=lxFvi50VRak

deck_excerpt: Budget 40-card Rokket Dragon Links.
deck_description: Obviously not the most meta thing on here, but for those of us on a budget, it should suffice.  In general, the idea is to Link Summon as much as possible to get out powerful monsters, usually the Link-4 Borrel Dragons.  Each one has its own form of protection and its own unique effects, so they're great in various situations.  You'll typically want at least one of the Borrel Dragons in play, usually Borreload or Borrelsword, backed up by a Rokket or two and a few other Link Monsters.  This deck is also capable of Synchro Summoning, so I've included Borreload Savage Dragon and Scarlight Red Dragon Archfiend, two of the best Level 8 DARK Dragon Synchros in the game.  If possible, you'll also want to get out Savage Dragon as an added measure of defense.  Ultimately, your goal is to beat your opponent down with continuous Borrel fire!  Whatever you open with, try to forge a clear path to a field of big monsters.  A good opening card is Starliege Seyfert since you can use it thin your deck by one card and still get Striker Dragon out, which then leads to more shenanigans with Rokkets in general.

deck_excerpt: Superheavy Samurai Samurai Destroyer
deck_description: If you know how to use SuperHeavy Samurais, then you're set. Basically, Superheavy Samurais can attack while in defense mode and their defense points act as their attack points. Providing good defense for a good offense. But if you need something that'll help your duel by attacking in attack mode, Samurai Destroyer will help you out without fail.  Note: Superheavy Samurais effects work best when you don't have spells and/or traps in your graveyard. In this deck, I added Sekka's Light. Knowing it works like Pot Of Greed, its additional effect will be able to banish itself so your graveyard is clear and you can be able to use Superheavy Samurai monsters effects without worry. However, using Sekka's Light means you cannot activate spell or trap cards yourself. Here's why, Warlord Susanowo's effect allows you to take spells or traps from your opponents graveyard and place them on your field so you can use them yourself, but if you used Sekka's Light at the start, Warlord Susanowo's effect would be useless and it'll cramp your Spell/Trap Card Zone which are needed for the Superheavy Samurai Soul cards. So use Sekka's Light if you need to gain an advantage and you're good.

deck_excerpt: Prank-Kids have 16 one card combos (similar to Zoodiac and Sky Striker at their best), and can set up a double Raigeki turn one! Have fun making combo
deck_description: I recently picked up Prank-Kids, and have fallen in love with the deck! Prank-Kids are a combo deck which can make some impressive end boards in 1-2 turns! Prank-Kids have 16 one card combos, and can set up a double Raigeki, and possibly Abyss Dweller/Apollousa/Accesscode turn one.  They can survive for quite awhile, but are extremely weak against Ash Blossom and other handtraps (cough* Nibiru *cough). The deck is highly vulnerable to backrow, so watch out for backrow heavy decks. If you'd like to know the main combo for the deck feel free to check out Therarely's Prank-Kids Deck Guide: https://ygoprodeck.com/deck-guide-connecting-your-prank-kids/ which helped build the deck better than I had done previously! I hope you enjoy playing Prank-Kids!

deck_name: Spooky Boi Hours Inferno Tempest Mill
deck_excerpt: Haha Funni Spooky deck that mills using Inferno Tempest, Kaijus, Necroface, and a wee bit of Mystic Mine. Also the backup plan is Amina beatdown.
deck_description: For my submission to the Yu-Gi-Oh spooky deck competition, I thought of the scariest thing I could, the inevitability of death. I decided against that idea at first because stall decks are lame as hell. Looking at my deck now you may be thinking that I am a horrible hypocrite, playing mine when I said stall was lame, however, there is one card that instills fear into the hearts of every man. Mystic Mine. But I thought that that may discredit the deck so I strayed away from using it too often. I found out later, that it facilitated my plays extremely well. I don't feel like I must explain the horror of getting hit by a meteor and of the other obvious cards, so now we will go into the "strategy" involved.   Inferno Tempest Mill. Mill. Mill. That is the name of the game when you play this deck, at least most of the time. The best play to make when you have this titular card is to tribute an opponent's monster into a 3000+ attack Kaiju then destroy your own 0 attack monster with it to activate the spell's effect. After all of the banishing, the Necrofaces activate, milling your opponent some more. If you have a Left Arm, you want to go for this card. To help you get to this card, we have a few stall items such as the Mystic Mine, and if you are in the DIREST OF STRAITS, you use a Kaiju and then go into Relinquished Anima to snatch up the Kaiju and gain the attack to just punch their face. The side deck is something you can choose on your own, find what you would enjoy for the deck. This is by no means to be taken as anything remotely viable and is just a fun casual deck.

deck_excerpt: Rogue Fluffal Deck for the September meta
deck_description: This is my current fluffal deck i'm using IRL, slightly updated.  It uses the Artifact engine and the Psy-frame engine with an emphasis on going first, but can easily switch to a going second variant using the side deck.  - Monsters (25)  Fluffal Dog x3: It searches any fluffal monster you need to continue your combos  Fluffal Penguin x3: Mostly used either as a special summon from toy vendor or as a fusion material to draw more, it allows you to make Bahamut Shark going first along with Dolphin, gets recycled by Toadally Awesome, and make link plays with bahamut or the special summon it gives you with it's first effect.  Fluffal Dolphin x1: It makes Bahamut Shark with Penguin, and allows Foolish Burial Goods to become a one card combo starter. Sending Toy Vendor to the GY from Deck, then normal summoning Dolphin to set Toy Vendor from the GY and send wing to the GY. His second effect rarely is used.  Fluffal Bear x2: Search Toy Vendor, our main advantage generating engine. Run at 3 because we want to have Toy Vendor as often as possible, I have cut it to 2 to reduce the card count to 40.  Fluffal Wing x1: Allows you to pop Toy Vendor by banishing itself and another fluffal from the GY, allowing you to draw 2 cards and search one from the destroyed vendor, it's only run at 1 because you rarely use it's effect more than once per duel, altho you can send Suture Rebirth to the GY and return it from the banished zone if needs be against grindy decks, that is why Suture Rebirth is in the side deck.  Fluffal Owl x1: Searches Polymerization (which is already easily searchable), it's second effect becomes live against Prohibition or any spell locking card allowing you to fusion without a spell.  Fluffal Sheep x1: Combo Extender, Special summons itself for link plays, if you search it from Dog and have Edge Imp Chain in hand, you can use it to send Dog back to hand, special Chain, make a link 2 and get chain's search effect.  Fluffal Cat x1: the other combo extender, has more uses going 2nd than first, but when going first can still allow you to put 2 fusions on board, either to make VFD or Dingirsu.  Edge Imp Sabres x1: Only at 1 because it is easily recycled by it's effect, it's used to make Tiger against backrow heavy decks, to link climb, overall a great card.  Edge Imp Chains x3: When sent to the GY from the hand or field, allows you to search a frightfur card. Most of the time used to search Frightfur Fusion for our XYZ plays, or Frightfur Patchwork to setup next turn.  Edge Imp Scythe x3: Our archetypal handtrap, can end the opponent's turn with a well placed destruction by summoning Frightfur Cruel Whale, allows us to use our artifact during the opponent's turn, and also protects our fusion monsters from destruction by banishing itself from the GY (most of the time used when Cruel Whale is the only monster on your field when you summon it)  Artifact Scythe x1: One copy, searchable by Dagda, Destroyable by Frightfur Cruel Whale with Edge Imp Scythe. Locking our opponent from the Extra Deck sometimes ends their turn here and there.  Psy-frame Gear Gamma x3: Our other handtrap, here to protect us from handtraps.  Psy-frame Driver x1: Just one copy to make Gamma live, can be summoned from the GY even when sent there by Toy Vendor.  - Spells (15)  Polymerization x3: Our fusion spell, nothing more to say.  Frightfur Fusion x1: Just one copy, easily searchable, using it to fusion summon a fusion monster by banishing from GY allows us to easily make rank 8 or 9 plays.  Frightfur Patchwork x3: Searches both Poly and an Edge Imp monster, fantastical to make even bad hand live.  Foolish Burial Goods x3: One card combo started, used to send Toy Vendor to the GY and making us search a fluffal monster or sabres, often than not you search Dolphin out of it, or Dog.  Toy Vendor x3: Most important card in the deck ? It's drawing effect can either make or break your turns, but it's search effect upon being sent to the GY is just too good.  Frightfur Repair x1: Sent to the GY with Frightfur Cruel Whale second effect. You never use the spell's first effect, but the second one allows you to extend your combos.  Instant Fusion x1: Used to bring out Winda while protecting her with Dingirsu in turn 1, often via Anaconda.     Extra deck (15)  Frightfur Cruel Whale x2: amazing card, on summon it destroys a card on both fields, non targetted, has a quick effect to send a frightfur card to the GY from either the main deck (Frightfur Repair) or the extra deck to boost the attack of a frightfur monster, you often use it's first effect to pop either scythe or toy vendor.  True King of All Calamities x1: Made from 2 Cruel Whales on first turn to stop the opponent from playing on his turn.  Frightfur Sabre-Tooth x1: Boosts all frightfur monsters' attack and on fusion, revives a frightfur fusion monster, giving us options for XYZ plays or just pushing for OTK. If fusion summoned with 3 materials, can't be destroyed by battle or effect.  Frightfur Kraken x1: Once upon a time it was our best fusion, now slightly outclassed by Cruel Whale, his non destruction effect is still tremenduous, and going second can easily lead to OTKs with his double attack. Using him to summon Sabre-Tooth allows us to reuse his card removal effect a second time, followed up by either an OTK or an XYZ 8 play. Him plus Sabretooth gives you just 8000 attack.  Frightfur Daredevil x1: Newly addded Beatstick, I've found myself using him more and more for the burn damage to push for the win. Can still be replaced with a third Cruel Whale or any other frightfur fusion if you don't like him, i've grown quite fond of him however.  Dingirsu, the Orcust of the Evening Star x1: Made from Kraken and Sabre-tooth, gives us a 3rd non destruction removal (but untargeted unlike kraken's) when going second, and when going first, protects Winda from Instant Fusion's destruction effect.  Frightfur Wolf x1: Often used via Frightfur Fusion by banishing our whole GY to have a 2k beater attacking a crazy lots of times.  Frightfur Tiger x1: On summon, destroys cards up to the number of materials used in it's summon, used to clear backrows.  Bahamut Shark x1: Made from Penguin and Dolphin, allows us to summon Toadally Awesome as a way to stop Nibiru during our turn, or just annoy the opponent on his.  Toadally Awesome x1: See above.  Cross-Sheep x1: Most often used for the fusion effect to extend our plays, he is the primary card enabling us to summon Bahamut Shark and Toadally.  Predaplant Verte Anaconda x1: Used when going first tu pitch Instant Fusion to make El Shaddoll Winda as a floodgate.  El Shaddoll Winda x1: Still a good floodgate nowadays when backed up by Dingirsu.  Artifact Dagda x1: Part of the Artifact engine to put out Scythe ready to be popped out by Cruel Whale on the opponent's turn.     On turn 1, your goal usually is to put out a mix of whichever you can put between VFD, Toadally Awesome, and Dingirsu/Winda.  In order to get VFD, you usually need 1 Fluffal monster, 1 Edge imp monster (most often chain), and a Polymerization with a Frightfur Fusion (which can be searched if using Chain as material). Use Polymerization with the monsters to summon the first whale, then search/use Frightfur Fusion and summon a second Whale by banishing the mats for the first fusion from the GY and overlay both whales to make VFD after using their effect to send Frightfur Patchwork to the GY from the deck to extend your potential plays.  If you summon Dagda and have Edge Imp Scythe in hand with another fluffal (penguin if possible), you can still lock the opponent from using the Extra deck by summoning Cruel Whale during the enemy turn. His destruction effect becomes CL 1, on that, use it's second effect as CL 2 to send Frightfur Repair to the GY, and use Dagda as CL 3 to set Artifact Scythe from the deck, so the opponent can't Cosmic Cyclone it as it will be set and destroyed in the same chain.  To summon Dingirsu, you'd need either 2 Polymerization or 1 Polymerization and Fluffal Cat,  an Edge Imp Monster (and 2 fluffals if not using cat) in order polymerize a Kraken, then use Kraken to polymerize Sabretooth with another monster which will then revive Kraken, and overlay both for Dingirsu (which nets you 3 non destruction removal if you do it going second by using kraken's effect after each time you summon him and with Dingirsu). If you have the required extender, you can then summon Predaplant Verte Anaconda and use it to copy Instant Fusion for a Winda as a floodgate, which will NOT be destroyed at the end phase thanks to Dingirsu, then during the opponent's turn, Winda can also survive an attack thanks again to Dingirsu (let it die at the end of the opponent's end phase to not gimp yourself tho)  Going second, you probably can scoop, but Kraken and Sabre-tooth will be the backbone of your plays. Most of the side deck is geared towards going second in a bo3.  Droll and Lock Bird is probably the best Handtrap in the meta against the top tier decks, able to single handedly force them to end their turns.  Lancea can be searched with the Dagda/Cruel Whale Combo if needed be to also stop them from playing their full combo.  Nibiru the Rock Jhonson is Nibiru, always useful.  Forbidden Droplet is the board breaking spell by excellence, i'd also run Lightning Storm but I don't have them (yet).  Harpie's Feather Duster for backrow heavy decks alongside Tiger.  Frightfur Reborn is against those stall decks, in order to get a second use of Fluffal Wing by banishing the spell from the GY to return Wings to the GY.  The last 3 fusions are here because I had nothing to replace them with yet.  The deck can definitely steal some wins here and there, and if you enjoy combo decks i'm sure you'll enjoy this deck too, you can most of the time play through one handtrap (depends which one of course), the Toy Vendor engine makes the deck quite good at cycling through the deck and the games usually are quick. Also Fluffals are cute.

deck_excerpt: As already seen in the past, Invoked and Blue-Eyes are decks that go well together, in this list we also find Cyber Dragon Infinity and the brand new
deck_description:
Introduction:  Main Level Monsters:4,8; Main Summons: Hand and Graveyard  ||  Extra Summons: Fusion, Xyz and Link. Key cards: Aleister the Invoker, Invocation, The Melody of Awakening Dragon. Tier Meta: Rogue Difficulty to use: 2/5
COMBO
Normal Summon Aleister the Invoker and search Invocation, link summon Salamangreat Almiraj and then Secure Gardna. Activate Invocation to summon Invoked Mechaba. Special summon Blue-Eyes Alternative Dragon, activate Return of the Dragon Lords to Sp Summon Blue-Eyes White Dragon. Summon Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Dragon then Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Ex Dragon and active it effect detaching the Cipher Dragon
Considerations
The Deck: The Blue-Eyes Invoked Deck is not bad, maybe it can still be fixed a little bit but it already has good stability. Thanks to the Invoked engine and the access to ranks 8 by Blue-eyes cards we find ourselves a nice control deck but also aggro. The Cards:
  • Aleister the Invoker is the key to the deck with which we add Invocation in the hand and we go to summon Invoked Mechaba.
  • Galaxy Soldier gives us access to Cyber Dragon Infinity, playing almost all monsters of light attribute, including hand traps, it is very easy to summon it by activating its effect.
  • Nebula Dragon is useful to more easily summon 2 levels 8, as well as being an additional Trade-in target.
  • Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Ex Dragon is a very useful pre-release currently ocg support, covering the monsters of attribute light. And in the next standby phase it allows us to return the Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Dragon in the extra deck and then immediately afterwards, summon it on top of Cipher Ex.

Final Board:

Usually Invoked Mechaba we always manage to summon him, besides him it would be great to be able to summon Galaxy-Eyes Cipher Ex Dragon, if we have Galaxy Soldier in hand we can opt to summon Cyber ​​Dragon Infinity.
Side Deck
The side deck is mainly focused on 3 things. In the first case we have simple cards that are the substitute for others, such like Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon Titanic Galaxy. In the second we have cards useful against other decks or generic staples, like Fantastical Dragon Phantazmay. And in the third and last we have, Super Polymerization with and attached cards.

-

Fantastical Dragon Phantazmay is great side card 'cause it's a dragon monster target of Return of the Dragon Lords and allows you to draw 1 or more cards and is can be used at the end of the board as an extra negation. Harpie's Feather Duster excellent card that cleans us the magic and traps section. Triple Tactics Talents can be the replacement for Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit or Effect Veiler and it's very useful to draw 2 which in this deck is worth a lot, since we need cards in hand, or discard a card in the opponent's hand. True King of all Calamities is too strong a card not to be played, it's not very easy to summon and that's why I keep it sideways.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MO9UQkinaXw&t=44s
